**Regulations on the Format of Memorials**
The decree states: For the method of memorial writing, do not leave the preceding document (*du*) too long—the paper should be convenient for the Supreme Mystery Capital (*Taixuandu*). The following are the rules:

1. The Supreme Mystery Capital’s *Zhengyi Pingqi* (Orthodox Unity’s Balanced *qi*) is addressed by this treatment’s *Zhengyi* minister [Name], who bows twice with reverence.
2. The memorial begins: "Respectfully examining the document, [Name] of [Prefecture, County, Township, Village], male/female, aged [Age], of [Household Name]."
3. "With grace, we beseech the Most High to distinguish and hear our plea. Your humble servant is sincerely awestruck and fearful."
4. Conclude with "I humbly report this" followed by another bow. Leave a one-inch gap below, and for those of lower status, use a separate sheet. The minister’s surname should be written at the top of the line.
5. Align the next sheet with the minister’s surname and the Year Star (*Taisui*) at the top of the line.
6. Align the next sheet with the *Taiqing* forty-eight-character text, written in three-inch characters.
7. Align the next sheet with the Year Star’s day, month, and hour, and present it with a bow in the middle of [Prefecture, Township, Village].
8. Leave three sheets blank afterward. The Three Masters’ spiritual endorsement (*Lingzan*) may be appended on additional paper if fewer than three sheets remain.
9. When ruling the paper for memorials, leave an eight-fen margin. The central ruling should also be divided as a standard.
10. The method for writing memorials must follow the above rules; do not arbitrarily alter the margins or sheet divisions.

The decree states: *Zhengyi* Daoists must observe the above regulations for the dignity and standards of memorial writing. These ten decrees forbid arbitrary changes to margins or sheets, or the creation of new methods that may confuse later learners. Violators who devise their own methods shall be subject to the *Zhengyi* Daoist Five Punishments. The Five Punishments are: labor service in the celestial administration, and the provision of 2,000 bundles of thatch for roofing.

11. The method for writing memorials requires placing a cloth beneath the paper; the paper must not touch the bed.
12. The paper must also be handled properly; do not let clothing brush against the memorial. Exercise caution.
13. When writing memorials, ensure the paper, brush, and inkstone are clean; do not allow contamination or mixed use.
14. When grinding ink, rotate the inkstick leftward forty-nine times and stop.
15. When holding the brush, rotate it left and right seven times each and stop; do not hold the brush tip in the mouth.
16. Do not engage in idle conversation while writing memorials.
17. The water used for writing must be clear and settled.
18. Do not dip the brush in water and drip it onto the inkstone.

18. When writing memorials, keep the mouth closed; do not eat or drink anything.
19. If the body is defiled or unclean, do not write memorials.
20. Select a hand towel to wash the hands, ensuring they are always clean.
21. Do not write corrupted characters. If a character is incomplete or incorrect, cease writing.
22. Do not allow the paper to tear or the brush to leak ink.
23. Do not let the memorial or paper fall to the ground; if it does, do not reuse it.
24. Do not continue writing after consuming meat or unclean food.
25. Do not continue writing while engaged in unclean or improper matters.

It is decreed: The above twenty-five articles are the regulations for writing memorials under the purview of the Office. They must be followed accordingly. Should one act with negligence or disobey these orders, the responsible Daoist priest shall be subject to the three penal statutes. The three penal statutes entail sweeping roads and bridges for thirty days.

26. When writing memorials, attire must be properly arranged; do not expose the body.
27. Approach with reverence, prostrating respectfully; do not squat or sit casually.
28. After completion, read and proofread the memorial once in private.
29. Omitted characters must be corrected using white ink and realgar.
30. Do not write characters carelessly.
31. Do not allow others to secretly read the memorial’s contents.
32. Do not pre-write the date and time of the Supreme Clarity audience; fill it in only when submitting.
33. After the Daoist priest seals the memorial, the host shall don a sash and request the memorial.
34. When the host requests the memorial, perform three bows, three prostrations, and three rises and descents, totaling nine stops.
35. When the host faces the memorial to bow, continue until the submission is complete. Offer personal prayers and express whatever is in the heart—petition for recovery from illness or state the matter at hand.
36. After the Daoist priest completes the submission of the memorial, the host shall express gratitude, bowing and prostrating as when initially requesting it.

The above thirty-six articles are from the *Orthodox Regulations on Writing Memorials*, the second section of the statutes. For all memorials and petitions, first purify oneself through fasting and bathing, wash the hands and face, and arrange one’s attire and cap. Enter the chamber, face the Celestial Gate, set up a seat, and burn incense according to the prescribed form.

The paper for writing memorials should be one foot nine inches in height, or one foot two inches, or one foot four inches as the standard. Use the ancient method of spreading silk on the table for writing.

In the Supreme Capital, the character "Supreme" (泰) should be one character higher than the line above it. Leave eight fen of space above the upper text, and ensure the lower text flows smoothly. Each line should contain seventeen characters, with a line width of one cun and two fen, or two cun and four fen. The first line should conclude with the official title, ending at the "bow twice" (再拜) characters. The upper text occupies its own line. The character "minister" (臣) must not begin a line, nor should "ghost" (鬼) appear at the start. Do not leave living names incomplete or dead names exposed, nor split or break personal names. Each name should occupy one character; even if a name consists of two characters, treat it as one. Characters related to souls, spirits, or the deceased must be avoided at the beginning of lines.

Do not allow outsiders to peek or permit chickens, dogs, or other animals to enter the chamber. While writing the memorial, do not speak to outsiders; hold the breath while writing. Do not set down the brush before completion. When facing the memorial, do not read it aloud in a harsh voice. Do not leave the seat before finishing. Do not let the incense burn out.

When writing "hear and depart" (以闻去), leave one cun of space above, and write "bow again" (再拜). If the text runs long, attach a separate sheet. The essentials of cultivating the Dao follow the same rules.

For *Cai Zhixu’s Rites*, write "report" (以闻) and "inform" (低告) as two characters. Leave three lines blank afterward, then write the minister’s name. Leave another three lines blank, then write the "Supreme Clarity Rank" (太清阶). After three more lines, write the "Great Year" (太岁). The "Great Year" and the minister’s name should be two cun and four fen lower than the upper text. The "Great Year" line should extend to the end of the row based on the number of characters. Leave three more lines blank; if space is insufficient, add another sheet of paper. The "Supreme Clarity Rank" should be tightly aligned.

According to the statutes, the "Supreme Clarity" (太清) consists of forty-eight characters, written in three cun. However, the current "Supreme Clarity Rank" contains fifty-six characters, eight more than the ancient statute. For *Cultivating the Dao’s Essentials*, omit the four characters "Golden Palace Seven Treasures" (金阙七宝), resulting in fifty-two characters, which also differs from the statute. This requires verification.

In the *Red Pine Master’s Calendar*, the fine characters of "Supreme Clarity" ascend three cun and five fen at the top, four cun and five fen in the middle, and five cun at the bottom, not exceeding these measurements. For *Liu Chongjing’s Rites*, write the minister’s name and "Great Year" each in one line of fine regular script. Write the memorial evenly and without delay. Fill in "Your Majesty" (陛下) without delay; the ancient method requires filling in "Supreme Clarity" (太清) without delay. Write the fine titles of "Supreme Clarity" below.

Have the fasting host don a sash and request the memorial. The Dharma Master submits the memorial facing east during the day and north at night.

For vermilion memorials, use even and clean yellow silk, writing in red. The height and measurements follow the same rules as the memorials. Each line should contain twenty-four characters, with a line width of one cun and two fen, or nine fen as the standard.

Those who write memorials must be meticulous. Do not allow characters to fade or crack, nor omit or miswrite them. Do not arbitrarily alter the memorial’s text to suit the fasting intent, ensuring coherence and avoiding breaks.

While writing the memorial, the Divine Officials, Merit Officers, and Twelve Writing Assistants oversee from the left and right. All merits and faults are recorded without omission. The prohibitions and solemnity herein are unparalleled. Exercise utmost care.

**Memorial Seal.**

**Regulations state:** For all memorials, one must first prepare the *xin* offering. If there is no *xin*, the divine spirits will not accept it, and you will be reproached for stinginess and reluctance to part with wealth.

It is further said: If a memorial lacks proper *xin*, the wealthy should increase it, while the poor may reduce it. Those of wealth and nobility, though desiring merit and virtue, cling to their possessions and merely imitate the poor in offering *xin*—such conduct is of no benefit. For impoverished scholars seeking to present memorials or perform *jiao* rites, the master may provide the ritual *xin* on their behalf. Though the old memorials specify different requirements, they generally follow these principles. The Son of Heaven, nobles, and commoners differ in rank, and their *xin* offerings vary accordingly; they must not be confused or treated without distinction.

The regulations further state: The items of *xin* should be distributed to the poor, thereby cultivating hidden virtue. The master must not use them all—only three parts out of ten may be retained. The celestial statutes are strict and severe; one must be cautious.

**Silk and Brocade:**
- The Son of Heaven uses purple silk, measured in *pi*.
- Nobles use silk of their life-destiny color, measured in *zhang*.
- Scholars and commoners use plain silk, measured in *chi*.

**Seal Money:**
- The Son of Heaven uses gold coins.
- Nobles use silver coins.
- Commoners use copper coins.

**Rice for Blessings:**
- The Son of Heaven: three *shi* and six *dou*.
- Nobles: two *shi* and four *dou*.
- Commoners: one *shi* and two *dou*.

**Sealing Oil:**
- The Son of Heaven: one *shi* and two *dou*.
- Nobles: six *dou* and four *sheng*.
- Commoners: two *dou* and four *sheng*, or one *dou* and four *sheng*.

**Incense for *Xin*:**
- The Son of Heaven: one full *jin*.
- Nobles: half a *jin*.
- Commoners: three to five *liang*.

**Brushes, Ink, Paper, and Cinnabar:** These are provided for the scribe to write the memorial. All memorials must be fully equipped with these; none may be temporarily lacking. The rest follows the original regulations.

**Memorial to the Mysterious Heavens:**
- Paper: one hundred sheets.
- Brush, ink, and inkstone: one set each.
- Writing knife: one.
- Gold fish: one.
- Jade geese: a pair.
- Incense: five *liang*.
- Firewood: fifty *jin*.
- Charcoal: fifty *jin*.
- Salt: one *jin*.
- Fermented beans: one *jin*.
- Oil: one *dou* and two *sheng*.
- Rice: one *shi* and two *dou*.
- Coins: one *guan* and two hundred *wen*.
- Clean cloths: two.
- *Mingxin* silk: as many *zhang* and *chi* as required.

For each additional memorial, provide:
- Rice: five *dou*.
- Coins: one *guan* and two hundred *wen*.
- *Mingxin* silk, paper, brush, ink, and inkstone as per the ritual.

**Method for Sealing the Memorial:**
After the memorial is proclaimed, place the writing knife before the Supreme Clarity. Position the gold fish and jade geese to the left and right of the Supreme Clarity. Envision the Divine Officials and Writing Assistants examining the memorial text, along with the new brush, ink, and inkstone placed before them. The High Priest rolls the scroll tightly within the incense smoke, inserts it into the case, and adds *naozi*. Secure it with three knots of green silk, then seal it in the wax pool. Enclose it again in a green paper case, and commit it to the purifying flames.

*Concluding the Tenth Scroll of* The Instantly Completed Rites of the Supreme Yellow Register Grand Fast.

*Eleventh Scroll*
*Transmitted by Master Chongjing of the Three Caverns, Left for Use by Master Liu Guang*
*Compiled by Jiang Shuyu, Celestial Enforcer of the Supreme Dao*
*Memorial Prayers*

Vermilion Memorial on Yellow Silk,

Your humble servant [Name], in solemn reverence, bows his head and prostrates himself, kneeling twice to address the Supreme, Boundless, and Utmost Dao—the Perfectly Real and Spontaneously Self-So—beneath the Golden Gates of the Heavenly Palace.

We, unworthy and foolish, have presumptuously partaken in the loftiest rites. Our merits are but specks of dust and dew, while our transgressions pile high as mountains. Overwhelmed with shame, body and soul lose their truth.

With utmost reverence, we bow our heads and prostrate ourselves again.

Truly, though base and insignificant, we have been fortunate to rely upon past blessings, undeservedly encountering the wondrous transformation and gratefully bearing the profound grace of the Mystery. Having been unworthily entrusted with the office of the Perfected, we are duty-bound to deliver and save. Though our nature is dull and blind, we vow to exhaust our sincerest devotion, pursuing the compassionate breeze and embracing the wondrous teachings. Seeing righteousness, we think of courage, day and night keeping it in our hearts. Given the karmic conditions at hand, how dare we not make this known?

Now, from [Place of Origin], there is one who enters the fast with the following intent: having never before undergone purification, they have learned of the Supreme Orthodox Rites of the Yellow Register Grand Fast, which dissolves the bonds of life and death, washes clean the sins of body, heart, mouth, and intent. It augments the imperial destiny above and extends to all living beings below, safeguarding the state and pacifying households, averting calamities and repelling harm.

May the nine generations of ancestors and the seven lineages of forebears be delivered and uplifted, all wandering souls be rescued, and the living be succored—may the radiance of wisdom and grace extend universally. With reverence, we present the golden dragon tokens of the ten directions as pledges of faith, along with life-thread silks, incense, oil, candles, and all requisite offerings for the fast and jiao rites, submitting our petition to the altar. We humbly beseech that at [Location], the Supreme Orthodox Yellow Register Grand Fast be established for three days and nights, culminating in the full dispersal of the three hundred and sixty-part offering of the thanksgiving purification jiao.

All merits thus accrued shall be dedicated to the deliverance of the deceased kin, [Name(s)], and universally to all souls in attendance for deliverance, including those within the household, distant ancestors, and extended kith and kin. May it further extend to the ten directions and nine nether realms, to imprisoned spirits and those burdened by sin, dissolving their karmic fetters and uplifting them to the realm of life. By this extraordinary cause, may it augment the state and family above, bring benefit and peace to all beings, and bestow blessings upon the living.

As the petition is earnest and sincere, we dare not refuse. Having already memorialized the Ten Heavens and pledged before the Three Realms, we now reverently lead the ordained Daoist priests, [Names], in accordance with the sacred protocols of the Lower Prime Yellow Register and the ranks of the numinous immortals. Following the celestial patterns and earthly forms, we establish the sacred altar. With the golden dragons and silken banners presented, we consecrate the ten directions, invoking heaven and earth to save the living and deliver the dead. Together, we exert our utmost devotion, purifying hearts and minds, prostrating in ashes and dust, and surrendering to the Supreme Perfection, that our prayers may be fulfilled.

For three days and nights, through nine dawns of ritual, we proceed in due order, proclaiming the true scriptures. We bow and present memorials to the Celestial Officials for deliverance, reciting the sacred titles of the Most High’s true scriptures. We issue talismanic decrees, absolving the nine nether realms, kindling lamps to perpetuate light, and invoking radiance to shatter the prisons of darkness. Universally, we offer boundless alms, summoning and nourishing the departed souls, guiding them to bathe and ascend the altar, to hear the scriptures and receive the Dharma. We transmit talismans and confer precepts, refining and delivering them to transcendence.

Gathering vast merit, we dedicate it wholly to their deliverance. Commencing on the [Day] of this month and concluding at [Time] on [Day], we reverently perform the rites to dissolve the altar, casting the dragon tablets into mountains and waters. With cinnabar and golden petitions, we memorialize the sacred altar. Prostrate, we present a vermilion memorial on yellow silk, that it may ascend to the Nine Heavens.

We implore the Most High, Boundless Dao, the Primordial Celestial Worthy of Numinous Treasure, the Most High Dao Lord, the Most High Lord Lao, the Most High Elder, and the Supreme Mysterious Elder, the Ten Directions’ Spontaneous Numinous Treasure Celestial Worthies, the perfected and sagely hosts, the most true lords and elders, the Great Emperors and Celestial Emperors, the Celestial Masters, and the Great Dharma Masters of the Mysterious Center. May they deign to regard our petition with compassion. Should it find favor before the throne, we beseech the pardon of those bound by judgment.

We proclaim to the Five Elder Lords of the Ten Directions, the Perfected Immortals of the Five Peaks, the Three Officials and Nine Bureaus, and the true numina of the Ten Realms: deliver the deceased [Name(s)], the souls in attendance for deliverance, and the household of the fast’s sponsor, including their hundred thousand ancestors across kalpas, all kith and kin through eons, the six paths and four modes of birth, suffering souls and sin-laden spirits—whether bound by affinity or not, whether foe or kin—granting all equal deliverance, that they may escape eternal night. From the nine nether realms, may they ascend to the Southern Palace, donning robes upon withered bones, restoring flesh to bloom. May the wheel of rebirth be exhausted, transforming them to enter the gate of blessings.

May the spirits guarding the land and the forms of the departed return to their original state, uniting with the luminous and the obscure. For the sponsor [Name]’s household, may all sins from past and present lives be swept away, dissolving calamities and dispelling harm. May misfortunes be averted, disasters dispelled, life prolonged, and destiny preserved. May the living and dead flourish, and kinfolk dwell in peace.

Above, may the seven luminaries shine brightly, and the two primal forces endure. May yin and yang harmonize, the five grains yield abundant harvests, the nation prosper, and the people live in peace. May the world attain great tranquility, the imperial destiny be prolonged, plagues and poisons vanish, and auspicious omens daily increase. May we eternally uphold the Dao’s grace, preserving primordial auspiciousness.

We now summon the celestial immortals’ legions, the earthly immortals’ legions, the flying immortals’ legions, the perfected beings’ legions, the divine beings’ legions, the legions of the sun, moon, and stars, the legions of the Nine Palaces and Five Emperors, the legions of the Three Rivers and Four Seas, and the legions of the Five Peaks and Four Waterways—each numbering nine hundred million cavalry. From the Thirty-Two Heavens, we invoke the overseers of the fast, the golden youths attending incense, the jade maidens scattering flowers, the direct emissaries of the Five Emperors, the messengers of proclamations, and the flying dragon couriers.

Within our bodies, we bear the ordained registers of inner and outer true immortals, the officials of the Numinous Treasure, the majestic spirits of the Three Treasures, the couriers of the Mysterious Capital’s golden dragons, the nine dragon messengers, the life-examining youths, the guardian spirits of the Dharma, the dragon-tiger cavalry, the generals of the Three Primes, the refining and deliverance officials of Southern Prosperity, the divine tiger pursuers, the city gods and earth deities, the local territorial deities, and the altar-monitoring deities of the Three Realms—all those who have been invoked to oversee this altar’s incense and flame, whose awe-inspiring power is manifest.

May all those who have been summoned to oversee, protect, and assist, who have diligently served the fast, be arrayed in full regalia. With this memorial, we present them to the Mysterious Capital, that they may be ranked and rewarded according to merit. May they ascend the true palaces, advance in immortal rank, receive titles and imperial appointments, and be enfeoffed according to their grade. May all ranks and degrees be exalted and attained, in accordance with the rites of the Perfected.

We, whose mastery of the Dharma is yet incomplete, may have erred in our bearing or transgressed the protocols, failing to meet the proper forms. We fear being censured by the Four Offices or seized by the Five Emperors. For our thousand faults and ten thousand sins, we beseech pardon and absolution. May our ignorance be met with compassion, and our transgressions go unseen.

Once the rites are complete, may the true officials within our five bodies return to their palaces, that we may study and attain the Dao, seek and achieve immortality, and forever become true persons. May we align with the three luminaries’ brilliance and endure with the five qi. We implore the Most High and all worthies to discern and show mercy.

With utmost reverence, we entrust this memorial to the flying immortal couriers of the Three Officials, the Orthodox Unity functionaries, the left and right official messengers, the yin-yang spirit-decision officers, the chariot-directing talisman couriers, the strong wind couriers, the memorial-delivering couriers, the flying dragon cavalry, and the celestial immortal cavalry—each twenty-four in number.

The officiating minister humbly undertakes the establishment of the Yellow Register Grand Fast for Official So-and-So, having completed the open-air petitions and now dissolving the altar to transfer duties. The celestial ranks are restored, and merits re-illumined. A vermilion memorial on yellow silk, one scroll in length, is respectfully presented to the Most High’s Such-and-Such Bureau, awaiting report and response.

This minister, with trepidation and reverence, prostrates and bows twice to make this known.

[Three blank lines]
Minister [Surname] of [Such-and-Such] Abbey, [Such-and-Such] Prefecture, [Such-and-South] County, engaged in purification through incense and devotion
[Three blank lines]
The Most High, Boundless and Nameless, Primal and Spontaneous, Perfect and True Great Dao, Supreme Heavenly Worthy Beneath the Golden Portals and Jade Towers

As Master Du Yi notes, this sacred title is to be inscribed by the Dharma Master at the time, with each character measuring two *cun* and four *fen*, filling the space entirely. If the space cannot be filled, the characters may be written in a single line in smaller script.
[Three blank lines]
On the [Such-and-Such] day of the [Such-and-Such] month in the [Such-and-Such] year of the reign era, when the Celestial Gate opens at the hour of [Such-and-Such], prostrated and presented at the Mystic Altar within the abbey
[Three blank lines]
The vermilion memorial is to be written on yellow silk measuring one *zhang* and two *chi*, backed with light yellow paper, and cut to a height of one *chi* and two *cun*. Each line shall contain twenty-four characters. If following the ancient method, each line shall be two *cun* and four *fen* in width. Should the text be too lengthy, the number of lines may be adjusted accordingly. As the memorial is termed "yellow silk," raw yellow silk should be used. However, Master Tian notes that raw silk is too soft for outdoor handling, and it is preferable to use thin paper as backing. The sacred title consists of twenty-four characters, with no three-character line—as recorded in the *True and Unified Spontaneous Scripture and Decisions*. For cases where the text may leak, a square box may be used, following the same method as for memorials. The memorial is to be presented without a seal.

**Memorial for Transmutation and Liberation**

The minister of such-and-such rank, [Surname], with trepidation and reverence, prostrates and bows twice.

To the right: This minister humbly pours forth his cinnabar sincerity, beseeching the celestial audience. In accordance with the intent of the fast, and as the stains of the past have never been cleansed, he respectfully requests that on the [Such-and-Such] day of the [Such-and-Such] month, at [Such-and-Such] place, the Supreme Yellow Register Grand Fast be inaugurated, lasting three days and nights before its conclusion. A thanksgiving purification rite shall be performed, with three hundred and sixty divine positions invoked. May the power of the Dao be relied upon to deliver the departed souls below. In accordance with the true statutes, the rites of transmutation and liberation shall be proclaimed and enacted, that the departed may return to form, transform their substance, and receive rebirth through transformation.

This minister, though base and insignificant, has been permitted to partake in the supreme Dharma. Overstepping his station, he presides over salvation, his duty lying in proclamation and transcription. Having received the command to submit, it would be improper to refuse.

With due reverence, this memorial is respectfully presented to the August Ancestral Master, the Northern Pole Purple Tenuity Great Emperor, and the August Ancestral Master, the Southern Pole Longevity Great Emperor—may Their Celestial Compassion deign to bestow Their sagacious decree, issuing proclamations to the Water and Fire Bureaus and the True Lords Governing the Five Marchmounts. May They vouchsafe the descent of the numinous roots of yin and yang, the True Water and True Fire. At this very hour of this very day, may They descend into the altar precincts to refine and deliver the departed, so-and-so and others. May their spirit-souls be clarified and rectified, their myriad qi wholly preserved; may their bodies radiate luminosity, and no demon dare assail them. May their spirits ascend to the Northern Palace, their ranks be conferred in the Southern Court. Humbly relying upon Your awe-inspiring radiance, may You graciously extend Your all-penetrating scrutiny.

This minister prostrates himself in profound submission, awaiting the manifestation of celestial grace. Presumptuously trespassing upon Your divine majesty, this minister is filled with awe and trepidation, kowtowing and knocking his head to the ground—worthy of death.

With due reverence, this memorial is respectfully presented for Your august perusal.

Respectfully submitted.

In the year of such-and-such *jiazi* of the Great Year, on such-and-such month and day, this memorial is presented by the titled minister so-and-so.

[Seal] May be disclosed

To the August Ancestral Master, the Northern Pole Purple Tenuity Great Emperor, and the August Ancestral Master, the Southern Pole Longevity Great Emperor—

This memorial is respectfully sealed and presented by the titled minister so-and-so. [Square Envelope]

A memorial in one sealed envelope is respectfully submitted to the Gate of the Three Heavens for presentation.

The titled minister [Name] respectfully seals it with double reverence.

*Pass-tally for the Day-Duty Merit Clerk*

To the Supreme Yellow Register Grand Fast Altar—

This altar now dispatches one sealed memorial, fully sealed and stamped, to be presented at the Gate of the Three Heavens. A pass-tally is hereby issued for immediate transmission.

To the Merit Clerk and Messenger on duty this day: receive this with clear accountability and proceed without delay. Ensure its timely passage through the cloud-borne journey, permitting no moment of obstruction or interception. Should any hinder its course, seize and deliver them to the nearest prison for punishment according to the law.

*Year, month, day, and hour of the Great Year recorded on the pass-tally*

*Prayer in Blue Script*

In the reign of the Great Ming, in the year [Year], cyclical year *jiazi*, on the [Day] of the [Month], the [Day] of the lunar cycle being *jiazi*, the titled minister [Name], of [Prefecture, Subprefecture, County], respectfully pours forth his sincere and mournful devotion, venturing to reach the celestial hearing.

Each states his intent for entering the fast:

For the *Principal Offering*—on behalf of this minister’s departed kin.

For the *Universal Offering*—on behalf of this minister and all others fortunate to partake, extending to those yet unabsolved.

Respectfully presenting ritual offerings, he petitions the Bureau of the Numinous Treasure Great Dharma to request one altar of Daoists. At [Place] Abbey or Temple, beginning on the [Day] of the [Month], he shall establish the Supreme Yellow Register Grand Fast for three days and three nights, conducting the Dao nine times daily. In advance, he shall follow the proper sequence, proclaiming the true precepts, bowing in submission of precious petitions, and issuing talismanic decrees.

Elevating the sin-laden souls, absolving those sunk in darkness.
Kindling lamps to perpetuate light, invoking radiance to shatter the prisons of the underworld.
Universally bestowing boundless grace—offering measured alms to summon the departed,
preemptively dedicating merit to the dead, bathing and reclothing them,
ushering them to audience with the Perfected, to hear the Dharma, to receive talismans and precepts,
refining and delivering them to transcendence and rebirth.
Upon completion, bowing to present memorials of merit,
casting dragon tablets and advancing petitions,
reverently arranging a pure jiao offering to the Three Hundred Sixty Divine Stations,
in profound gratitude for the vast grace above.

Each restates his intent for entering the fast:

For the *Principal Offering*—solely relying upon the compassion of the Dao.

For the *Universal Offering*—drawing upon the merit thus accrued,
extending to blessings for the living.
With reverence and awe, prostrating and bowing deeply,
he respectfully addresses the Supreme Boundless Dao,
the Most Perfect and Transcendent,
the Thirty-Six Divisions of Venerable Scriptures,
the Sacred Writings and Precious Talismans,
the Three Supreme Honored Ones,
the Ten Directions’ Assembly of Sages,
and the Great Dharma Masters of the Mystic Realm.

This minister, in presenting this petition,
finds his heart incapable of bearing the weight of gazing upon the celestial,
yearning for the sagely presence with utmost urgency and trepidation.
Thus, he humbly submits.

The inner seal shall employ yellow paper of three inches,
with a waist seal bearing this minister’s name,
and the Dharma Master’s name transcribed.
The memorial shall be prepared as an *advancing petition*,
its paper matching that of the *blue-green memorial*,
its height determined by the petition’s length.
Enclose the blue-green memorial within a square case for dispatch.

**Format for Writing Memorials**

For *blue-green memorials*, use only the finest blue-green paper, ensuring no stains, blemishes, or tears. If the paper is thin, affix two sheets back-to-back, each measuring one foot and two inches in height. Only one sheet may be used. The text should span no more than seventeen lines in total, front and back. While lines may be closely spaced, leave half a sheet blank at the end. After the character *wei* (維), begin each line flush with the margin. Leave eight *fen* of space at the top, and allow the text to extend fully to the bottom. The number of characters per line is unrestricted, though precise, small regular script is ideal. Following the invocation of the Sage, the subsequent text must not exceed sixteen sentences. Address the matter directly, ensuring brevity without ornamentation and substance without redundancy. Avoid ostentatious language or excessive embellishment; simplicity is paramount.

The paper for writing memorials must not be allowed to drift onto beds, mats, or the ground, nor should sleeves or clothing brush against the text. When writing, retire to a quiet chamber. The desk should be draped with a fresh cloth, and only vermilion brushes and inkstones—unused for impure purposes—are to be employed. Hold fragrant herbs in the mouth, hold the breath while writing, and take care not to exhale onto the text. If the writing falters, do not set the brush down, nor speak to others. The memorial must be completed in a single sitting; it may not be left unfinished overnight. The character *chen* (臣) must not appear at the start of a line, nor may a person’s name be split across lines.

These are the standards for writing memorials. Even minor deviations may not only fail to reach their destination but also invite misfortune.

The above is excerpted from the *Rituals of the Yellow Altar* by Ren Zhongsheng, which contains many detailed prescriptions, making abbreviation difficult. Adding a few lines is permissible, provided ample blank space remains at the end.

**Memorial for Opening the Scriptures**

From the humble official [Name], of the [Province] Administration Commission, [Prefecture/Subprefecture/County], with utmost sincerity, I present this memorial to beseech the vast and boundless Dao.

I, your servant, humbly submit the purpose of this fast and the requisite ritual implements for the offering. I respectfully petition the *San Dong* Master of Daoist Rituals, the Venerable [Name], to dispatch a Daoist priest to establish a sacred altar at [Location], where the rites of the fast shall be conducted.

**Primary Purpose of the Fast:**
For the principal offering, the merit begins with the compassion of the Dao.
For the universal offering, the merit arises from the accumulated virtues.

All shall receive blessings and protection. On the [Day] of the [Month], it was foretold that the sacred intent would first be proclaimed, ascending to the heavens. The fast shall commence on the [Day] of the [Month]. If no date has been fixed, it shall be stated: "A day shall be chosen hereafter to inaugurate the fast altar, reverently following the mysterious canons and proclaiming the secret traditions."

The fast shall proceed with the proper rites for three days and nine audiences. The ten directions shall be invoked and thanked, and the three realms shall be pledged. Upon completion, a grand thanksgiving offering of three hundred and sixty parts shall be conducted to express gratitude. May the boundless grace descend, universally aiding those lost in the depths.

All the sacred worthies of the three realms, the divine overseers of the ten directions, and the myriad numinous presences within and beyond the altar shall be reverently offered to. This shall also aid the grieving souls of the departed and universally deliver the suffering spirits.

The sacred scriptures of the Most High and the august titles of the Heavenly Worthies shall be respectfully recited beginning on the [Day]. The items to be presented are enumerated as follows:

First, the Daoist priest is requested to recite:
- *The Marvelous Scripture of the Uppermost Numinous Treasure for the Limitless Salvation of Humanity* (several fascicles)
- *The Marvelous Scripture of the Numinous Treasure of the Mysterious Dao for Ascending to the Dao, Dispelling Disasters, and Protecting Life* (several fascicles)

The above shall be universally dedicated and offered to the sacred worthies, divine multitudes, overseers, and guardian spirits of the three realms and ten directions.

Second, the Daoist priest is requested to recite:
- *The Marvelous Scripture of the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy on Saving from Suffering* (several fascicles)

The above shall be dedicated and offered to the netherworld officials, overseers, and all numinous presences presiding over the altar.

Third, if other scriptures, rituals, or repentances are to be recited, they shall be listed separately. For example:
- *The Marvelous Scripture of the Uppermost Numinous Treasure for the Limitless Salvation of Humanity* (several fascicles)
- *The Scripture of the Nine Heavens’ Spontaneous Generation of the Divine Chapters* (several fascicles)
- *The Marvelous Scripture of the Numinous Treasure Ninefold True Precepts, the Golden Register, and the Salvation from the Nine Hells* (several fascicles)
- *The Marvelous Scripture of the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy on Saving from Suffering* (several fascicles)
- *The Scripture of the Primordial Heavenly Worthy on Ascending to Heaven and Attaining the Dao* (several fascicles)
- *The Central Chapter of the Primordial Numinous Writ* (several fascicles)
- The august titles of the Jade Emperor, Great Heavenly Worthy of the Mysterious Heaven (several invocations)
- The august titles of the Heavenly Worthy of Great Compassion and Salvation (several invocations)
- The august titles of the Heavenly Worthy of Salvation from the Nine Hells (several invocations)
- The august titles of the Numinous Worthies of the Ten Grotto-Heavens (several invocations)

The above merits shall be dedicated to deliver the deceased [Name], enabling rebirth in the immortal realms.

For the universal offering, it shall be stated: "All souls present in this assembly shall each ascend to the immortal realms."

Fourth, the Daoist priest is requested to recite:
- *The Marvelous Scripture of the Uppermost Numinous Treasure for the Limitless Salvation of Humanity* (several fascicles)
- *The Scripture of the Nine Heavens’ Spontaneous Generation of the Divine Chapters* (several fascicles)
- *The Marvelous Scripture of the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy on Saving from Suffering* (several fascicles)
- *The True Scripture of the Primordial Heavenly Worthy on Ascending to Heaven and Attaining the Dao* (several fascicles)
- *The Central Chapter of the Primordial Numinous Writ* (several fascicles)

Each scripture and title shall be meticulously enumerated.

The above merits shall be dedicated to the deliverance of the departed, extending to all within the lineage, each ascending to the immortal realms. Any additional names to be included in the dedication shall be meticulously enumerated as follows.

The Daoist priest is requested to recite:
- *The Marvelous Scripture of the Uppermost Numinous Treasure for the Limitless Salvation of Humanity* (several fascicles)
- *The Scripture of the Nine Heavens’ Spontaneous Generation of the Divine Chapters* (several fascicles)
- *The Marvelous Scripture of the Numinous Treasure Nine Perfected Wondrous Precepts for Deliverance from the Nine Hells and Remission of Sins* (several fascicles)
- *The Marvelous Scripture of the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy on Saving from Suffering* (several fascicles)
- *The True Scripture of the Primordial Heavenly Worthy on Ascending to Heaven and Attaining the Dao* (several fascicles)
- *The Central Chapter of the Primordial Numinous Writ* (several recitations)
- The sacred titles of the Jade Emperor, Supreme Heavenly Worthy, and Lofty Sovereign of the Mysterious Heavens (several invocations)
- The august titles of the Heavenly Worthy of Great Compassion and Salvation (several invocations)
- The august titles of the Heavenly Worthy of Deliverance from the Nine Hells (several invocations)
- The august titles of the Heavenly Worthy of Vermilion Mound and Deliverance of Lives (several invocations)

The above merits shall be dedicated to the deliverance of all beings across the six paths and four modes of birth, and all wandering souls and lingering spirits, that each may depart from suffering and together attain rebirth and completion.

To the right, with reverence, we present the profound ritual codes and treasured scriptures of the sacred canon, serving as the bridge for salvation from suffering and the ladder for the deliverance of the departed.

Relying upon these sublime and wondrous means, we dedicate them to the salvation of those lost in delusion.

We earnestly recall the departed kin, [Name], and as in the universal dedication, the names of those sponsored by the assembly leader shall be placed foremost, followed by all the departed souls within this assembly. Having traversed the depths of worldly dust, their souls now dwell in distant realms. Fearing that their karmic conditions remain unfulfilled, their transformation into immortals may yet be delayed. We pray that through the merit of the true teachings, like the gentle seep of water, all consciousness adrift in the sea of suffering may be universally delivered.

Before proclaiming the sacred texts, we first open the jade-bound scriptures. We humbly beseech the all-hearing wisdom of the divine to graciously accept this petition of prior supplication.

Your servant, unable to contain his awe and longing in gazing upon the heavens and yearning for the sagely, prostrates himself in utmost reverence.

Respectfully submitted this memorial for your perusal.

Memorial respectfully presented.
In the year of [Year], on the [Day] of the [Month], your official servant [Name], memorialist.

*Memorial to the Five Emperors*
Presented by [Name], in his official capacity.

Upon reviewing the prior petition from [Village/Place of Origin], wherein the intent to enter the retreat was declared—though yet unpurified—devout offerings of ritual tokens were respectfully presented to the Great Ritual Bureau of the Numinous Treasure. A request is hereby made to select the [Day] of [Month] for the establishment of the Supreme Yellow Register Grand Retreat at [Location], to be held for three days and nights. Upon its completion and dispersal, a thanksgiving purification rite shall be conducted. The intent to re-enter the retreat is again declared, extending blessings to the living. As this servant finds the words too pressing to suppress, having already transcribed the petition for the imperial threshold, he humbly beseeches the venerated masters to memorialize the Ten Heavens and ally the Three Realms. The altar rites are now solemnly prepared, and the ritual seats strictly arrayed. This servant, leading the fellow Daoist priests of the retreat, reverently selects this evening to inaugurate the numinous altar, dividing its light to dispel darkness, arranging the ritual pledges, and unfolding the true scriptures. At dawn on the morrow, the retreat shall commence in earnest. For three days and nine audiences, the ritual codes shall be proclaimed, delivering the suffering from the hidden realms and repenting transgressions. May the radiance of grace be hoped for from above, and the attestation of deliverance be bestowed from below. This petition is respectfully submitted for your perusal.

To the right: The Dao of the Five Elders is revered, born of the same primordial qi; their virtue crowns the Three Powers, nurturing the myriad spirits under their unified governance. They are the object of faith for humans and heavens, the refuge for the living and the dead. In initiating this retreat, how dare we neglect reverent invocation? With utmost respect, we address the Celestial Lords of the Five Directions, the Five Numinous Ones, the Five Elders, and the Five Emperors: you who transform and cultivate all beings, who unfold the myriad perfected. You record meritorious deeds and ever observe the affairs of retreats. May your heavenly compassion widely extend, and your sagely blessings reach afar. Release the five-colored radiance to rescue those languishing in the depths of darkness. May the retreat’s merit be perfectly accomplished, and the names of the living be eternally inscribed upon the Cinnabar Terrace; may the repentance and thanksgiving be heard, and the records of transgressions wholly erased from the Black Registers. Relying upon the gift of your refining grace, may the work of protection and deliverance be fulfilled. May blessings shower upon the state and family, and grace extend to both the hidden and the manifest. This servant’s heart is overwhelmed with awe and longing, prostrate in utmost reverence. Respectfully submitted this memorial for your perusal.

Memorial respectfully presented.
In the year of [Year], on the [Day] of the [Month], your official servant [Name], memorialist.

**[Memorial for Altar Opening]**
Your servant, [Dharma rank] [surname and given name], with utmost sincerity, prostrates and offers this plea to the boundless Dao.

Previously, in accordance with the memorial to the Five Emperors, this servant invoked the covenant of the Three Realms, reverently following the prescribed order to proclaim and expound the true statutes. Bowing in submission, I presented the sacred writs and issued the talismanic decrees, delivering the sin-laden and opening pardon for the submerged. I burned incense and lit lamps, established the retreat, and performed the Dao. Invoking radiance to shatter the prisons, I universally bestowed the nocturnal retreat. Summoning and gathering the departed souls, I bathed and refined them for deliverance. Transmitting talismans and conferring precepts, I safeguarded and recommended them for transcendence. Upon completion of these rites, I presented a memorial to report the merits, offered the dragon tablets, and submitted the bamboo slips. Solemnly arranging the pure jiao offering, I gave thanks for the vast grace. Broadly accumulating virtuous merit, I collectively aided their ascent and deliverance. Thus, with the altar rites now solemnly prepared, together with the memorial to the Five Emperors, I humbly submit this report.

To the right, with utmost reverence: having meticulously prepared the yellow altar and fulfilled the rites, I dutifully adhered to the protocols of devotion. Gazing toward the purple celestial gates, I present these words, humbly hoping for the grace of your observation. With all sincerity, I reveal the sincerity of this retreat.

Reverently considering the boundless and limitless Great Dao of the Most High, the true and supreme scriptures of the Thirty-Six Divisions, the sacred talismans and true writs, the Three Venerable Ones of the Most High, the sacred assemblies of the ten directions, and the presence of the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center—these unfold the five sections and establish the myriad standards. The soaring mysteries congeal qi, naturally forming the texts of the Empty Cavern; the Lower Prime unites the spirits, thus establishing the ranks of the numinous immortals. They safeguard the kalpas and protect both the hidden and manifest. This unworthy servant, by virtue of the master-disciple bond, has presumptuously transmitted these wondrous teachings. Thus, I have followed the statutes in reverent observance, daring to proclaim and enact them without transgression. I have earnestly exhorted my Dharma disciples to faithfully adhere to the prescribed forms, establishing covenants and pledges to jointly accomplish the merits of the retreat.

I humbly pray that the Three Treasures bear witness and the myriad spirits descend in response. May you incline your radiance and turn your celestial carriage to oversee the deliverance of beings. In the dark realms of earth and water, may the compassion of the Dao open the path to salvation; in the lands illumined by sun and moon, may the power of wisdom shine forth. May blessings universally extend to the state and its households, and grace pervade both the living and the departed.

Your servant, overwhelmed with awe as I gaze toward the heavens and long for the sacred presence, prostrates in utmost reverence. Respectfully submitted this memorial for your perusal.

Memorial to the Divine Officials of the Ten Directions.
The Dharma-ranked [Name] has reviewed the memorial for the return of the Three Officials, which concerns the covenant binding the Three Realms. The present altar rites are now solemnly prepared, and the Dharma assembly is strictly arrayed.

I humbly lead the assembled Daoist priests of this retreat to reverently select this night for the establishment of the sacred altar. Splitting light to dispel darkness, we set forth the pledges of faith and unfold the true writ. At dawn on the morrow, the purification fast shall begin. We shall proclaim the ritual codes and confess transgressions. Herewith, brush, ink, paper, and inkstone are arrayed to secure the Ten Directions. We beseech that our memorial be transcribed and presented, that grace may be bestowed from on high, and deliverance granted to both the living and the departed. This memorial is respectfully submitted for your attention.

It is further humbly stated:
The Brahma-qi suffuses the vastness of the ninefold heavens;
The True Capital stretches boundlessly through the towering realms of the ten poles.
To ensure our sincerity ascends and is heard, we rely upon the sagely grace that descends in aid.

We reverently invoke the boundless worlds of the Ten Directions, the palaces of sun and moon, the sacred lands of scriptures and treasures, the earth and water, and the divine officials of the ten realms of immortals. May this memorial be conveyed before the sacred hosts. The True and Constant respond with goodness; the sagely transformation knows no bounds. Each time they descend to the altar, they serve as the conduit for our words.

We humbly pray that the virtue of boundless compassion be widely extended, and the merit of universal deliverance be broadly bestowed. In offering thanks to the Ten Directions, both far and near, we pray for mutual resonance; in presenting our sincerity through ninefold memorials, all faults and transgressions may be encompassed and concealed.

May it be that our intent ascends to meet the radiance of grace, and below, purification reaches all. The karmic deeds of the conditioned realm shall be elevated into boundless merit. May both the living and the departed universally partake in the blessings of life and transformation.

Your subordinate, with utmost reverence and urgency, respectfully submits this memorial for your perusal.

Respectfully submitted.

Memorial submitted to the Divine Assemblies of the Ten Directions, the Transmitting Immortals and Divine Officials—each undersigned, with reverent double seal.

Threefold covenant established for the Supreme Yellow Register Grand Fast.

Now, on behalf of the Grand Fast Master of the Supreme Yellow Register residing in [Village, Prefecture, and Location], [Name], together with the convener of the grand assembly, [Name], and all attending officials, scholars, and commoners, we have prepared offerings of patterned silks from the Ten Directions, golden dragon jade seals, and pledges of sincerity. We invite [number] Daoist masters to the [Temple Name] in [Prefecture and Location], to commence the altar rites on the eve of [Month and Day], conducting the Supreme Yellow Register Grand Fast for three days and nights. Upon its completion, we shall hold a thanksgiving purification rite, encompassing the three hundred and sixty divine ranks.

Our intent is to benefit the state and the household above, and to deliver the deeply afflicted below. To transcend the departed ancestors and safeguard the living. Thus, we turn to the supreme orthodox Dharma—the Supreme Yellow Register Grand Fast. It harmonizes Heaven and stabilizes Earth, protects the state and secures the household. It universally delivers the living and the dead, awakening all to the true Dao.

In accordance with the ancient mystic canons, we emulate Heaven and model Earth, erecting the altar and unfurling the registers. Pledges of sincerity are arrayed in the hall of splendor, while our petitions ascend to the golden gates. Solemn and reverent, we approach as though in the presence of the divine, purifying all with utmost care.

This endeavor depends entirely upon the participants of this fast, who together pledge their covenant, purifying their inner vision. For the essence of fasting lies in fasting the heart: severing the allure of sight, sound, and form; restraining the tongue from flavors and the nose from fragrances. Exhaling to clarify the qi, embracing the spirit in stillness.

Thus, our Supreme Polar Ancestral Master left these regulations: at the outset of the fast, one must first receive the Ten Precepts of solemn deportment. Penalties and statutes are established to ensure mindfulness without transgression, conduct upright in every gesture. Burning the Black Registers, illuminating the Crimson Writs—seven generations of ancestors ascend to Heaven, the Nine Dark Realms are delivered. All sentient beings, without exception, partake in this grace.

Now, the Grand Fast Master [Name] and the assembly, led by [Name], turn to our Dharma gate, taking refuge in the Great Dao. They undertake this fast for the state and the household, delivering the living and the dead, universally bestowing grace upon all beings. Bearing the Dharma’s pledge, they beseech its transmission.

I, lacking immortal virtue, have been unworthily summoned to this task. Truly, I am filled with trepidation and shame, yet cannot decline. I vow to exhaust my sincerity and strive to fulfill my duty.

Today, with all participants of this fast, we jointly swear before the Three Officials and pledge before the Five Emperors, mutually exhorting one another to complete the fast’s merit. Should any violate the precepts, profane the celestial perfected, and refuse correction, we invoke the Three Officials and Five Emperors to subject them to the trials of wind and blade, consigning them eternally to the abyssal chasm.

We respectfully request that each sign their Dharma rank, composing three copies of this covenant. Two shall be presented to the Three Officials and Five Emperors, while one shall remain in the Supreme Mystery Capital for reference.

Respectfully submitted in covenant.

**Proclamation of the Ten Precepts of the Ancient Dao**
*Altar of the Supreme Yellow Register Great Fast*

Those who undertake the fast must withdraw in reverent silence to a secluded chamber, mastering their emotions and nature.
Secure the gates of the spirit, preventing external burdens from entering.
Uphold the Ten Precepts, ensuring worldly attachments do not arise.
Cultivate a heart of courage and vigor, practicing the Ten Daoist Practices.
Firmly establish resolve, unshaken and unwavering.
Turn toward the profound and savor the true, with every thought purified—this is the essence of the fast.

The Ten Observances are as follows:

1. Bathe in fragrant water to purify the spirit and qi.
   Cleanse the five limbs and brighten the nine orifices.
   Clothing must be immaculate, both within and without redolent with fragrance.
   Thus may the August Emperor descend and the true spirits draw near.

2. Abandon worldly affairs and sever mundane ties.
   Withdraw from all distractions, practicing effortless non-action.
   Still the mind and body, focusing thought with single-minded devotion.

3. Abstain from rich flavors at the midday meal, curbing desires.
   Balance excess and deficiency, harmonizing the organs.
   Purify the spirit and qi, nurturing the mysterious spring within.

4. Maintain dignified attire and solemn demeanor.
   Cast aside arrogance and sloth, never neglecting reverence.
   In prostration, bowing, and ritual, observe strict decorum.

5. Seal the lips and silence speech, avoiding idle words.
   Regulate the voice and rectify the qi, reciting and chanting scriptures.
   Thus may humans and spirits awaken, and gods and immortals respond.

6. Purify the mind, banishing wayward thoughts.
   Subdue the six senses and eradicate the three poisons.
   Preserve the spirit and contemplate the true, penetrating the subtle and profound.

7. Burn incense and offer smoke, sound the drum to summon the spirits.
   May the Three Clarities hear above, and the Ten Directions be universally proclaimed.

8. Repent and confess transgressions, supplicating with prayers and vows.
   With sincere devotion and earnest supplication, express remorse and compassion.

9. Cultivate boundless compassion, pitying all who suffer calamity and distress.
   May all be delivered, their lives and deaths at peace, no longer enduring hidden torments.

10. In movement and stillness, maintain grace and refinement.
    Guide one another, speaking only of the Dao, never straying from the Dharma.
    Should any lapse or error be perceived, immediately acknowledge fault and repent with bowed head.

This proclamation is issued in the Hall of Pure Emptiness and Silent Repose.
All Daoist clergy and laity undertaking the fast are enjoined to comply.

**Proclamation.**
*Dated: [Year] [Month] [Day]*
*Proclaimed by: [Rank] [Name] [Seal]*

**Proclamation of the Oath**
*Altar of the Supreme Yellow Register Great Fast*

By the decree of the Mysterious Master and the Dao, this altar is established to invoke Heaven’s grace and universally bless the hidden and manifest realms.
Together with all the divine bureaus, celestial generals, marshals, and functionaries—golden lads and jade maidens, spirit officials and divine guardians—we pledge to protect the ritual altar and attend the true deities.
Let the oath be proclaimed; all shall heed with reverence.

We conduct the fast by command of the Master’s altar.
We guard it with utmost care, practicing it with solemn diligence.
The Great Dao cherishes life, delivering all without exception, reaching down to the earthly prisons and opening the gates of Heaven.
At the threshold of life, no harm shall befall the living, nor shall the ghostly path know ruin.
Our actions must be upright, our duty to prevent deceit.
Talismans and memorials are presented to the Three Realms, universally proclaimed above Heaven and below Earth.
To the water palaces and sacred mountains, in every moment of departure and return, clouds shall fly and traverse.
The Mysterious Altar is rectified; those who uphold the Dharma must act with impartiality.
We support filial piety and righteousness, subduing demonic forces and malevolence.
The dead and living receive deliverance, riding talismans and dragons in ascent.
Upon the fast’s conclusion, we ascend to the Celestial Ancestors and the Five Emperors to record merits.
The Three Officials shall review our deeds, elevating rank and advancing position.
Our names shall stand in the azure vault—should any grow lax, the sin shall be theirs alone.
Should any violate this oath, Heaven shall bestow its blade upon them.
Strive, strive! Let none fail in their duty.

Thus is the proclamation issued; let none claim ignorance.

**Oath as above; all shall uphold their duties.**
**Proclamation.**
*Dated: [Year] [Month] [Day]*
*Proclaimed by: [Rank] [Name] [Seal]*

**Proclamation to the Ritual Officers for Universal Salvation**
*Altar of the Supreme Yellow Register Great Fast*

This altar reverently follows the *Flying Celestial Wondrous Writ of the Numinous Treasure* and the secret canons of the primordial scriptures, establishing the Supreme Yellow Register Great Fast to deliver the hidden souls and bless the living.
In accordance with the Heavenly Worthy’s words, whenever a fast is conducted and the Dao practiced, the Four Heavenly Emperor-Kings shall arrive in flying clouds and green chariots, their jade carriages of eightfold splendor.
Attended by perfected persons and jade maidens bearing floral banners, phoenix songs leading before and celestial chimes following behind.

**Proclamation.**
*Dated: [Year] [Month] [Day]*
*Proclaimed by: [Rank] [Name] [Seal]*

Lions and white cranes, roaring and singing in harmonious chorus.
Burning incense and scattering flowers, they drift through the void to arrive,
gazing in reverence, practicing the Dao, beholding and listening to the Dharma’s sound.
The Ten Thousand Saints descend to the hall, the Thousand Perfected halt their chariots.

All who join this fast must walk with measured, refined steps and compose their minds in tranquil intent.
In sitting, rising, lying, or resting, they shall not depart from proper decorum.
Thus shall the Heavenly Kings rejoice, and their names be inscribed in the Upper Clarity.
Having already memorialized the various heavens and notified the Three Realms,
they form alliances and take vows, reverently upholding this precious fast.

A special missive is sent to request the City God of this prefecture, the deity So-and-So,
along with the assembled spirits, to oversee and guard the numinous altar,
sweeping away defilements and impurities.
They shall reverently welcome the sacred chariot and deliver both the living and the dead.

We humbly invite the fast’s officiating officers, the gentry, and the common people to the altar,
to bear witness and offer incense, devoting their utmost sincerity in shared prayer for divine favor.
The talismanic petitions, merit certificates, and precept scrolls shall await the completion of refinement and deliverance,
then be sent to the Bridge of Numinous Deliverance for unified burning.

The altar’s supervising deity, So-and-So, has been requested to dispatch officers and clerks
to verify the departed souls, assigning each a separate memorial,
so that the merits of the fast may find their proper destination.

All participating devotees are earnestly reminded:
none may presume to act out of turn or burn offerings on their own,
lest disorder arise and the fast’s merit be tarnished.
This must be made clear.

**Proclamation.**
Let all take heed.
*Dated: [Year] [Month] [Day]*
*Proclaimed by: [Rank] [Name] [Seal]*

**Notice of Duties**
*Altar of the Supreme Yellow Register Great Fast*

This altar, acting on behalf of the chief patron of the Yellow Register Great Fast, So-and-So,
now offers this fast to directly deliver the deceased kin So-and-So,
and universally deliver all souls gathered in this assembly,
erecting the Supreme Yellow Register Great Fast.

Beginning on the [Day] of this month and continuing until the night of [Day],
when the fast concludes, a grand fast shall be conducted to offer thanks for boundless grace.

All Daoist participants in this fast must adhere to their designated roles and duties.
Having already sent out invitations and established sworn alliances,
lest any oversight occur during the proceedings,
the following offices and their respective duties are hereby enumerated:

**High Merit Master of the Great Dharma**
[Rank] [Name] So-and-So
His duty: his inner virtue is full, his outward demeanor impeccable.
In every movement and stillness, he embodies the Dharma’s form.
He is the model for the Three Realms, the gaze of gods and spirits.
He petitions and invokes blessings, communicates with the Perfected, and summons spirits.
He resolves doubts, dispels obstructions, and guides the assembly of worthies.

**Lector Master**
[Rank] [Name] So-and-So
His duty: his talent and wisdom are keen, his mastery of ritual precise.
During the practice of the Dao, in all matters of eating, resting, rising, or sitting,
he shall first report to the Dharma Master, then lead the assembled officers.
In bowing, yielding, or deferring, he shall intone the proper chants.

**Supervising Fast Master**
[Rank] [Name] So-and-So
His duty: he oversees the assembly’s transgressions, correcting faults and errors.
Holding fast to the canons and statutes, he reports all matters as they arise.
He must ensure all is just and proper, allowing no concealment or leniency.

**Scripture Attendant Master**
[Rank] [Name] So-and-So
His duty: he safeguards the sacred scriptures and arranges the central repository.
The high seat, the lectern, and the seating on all four sides—
he ensures all is neat and orderly, never lax or negligent.

**Incense Attendant Master**
[Rank] [Name] So-and-So
His duty: he tends to the censers and vessels, keeping the fire lit and the ash clean.
During the three periods of Dao practice and the two sessions of scripture recitation,
he shall prepare all in advance, ensuring nothing is lacking when needed.

**Lamp Attendant Master**
[Rank] [Name] So-and-So
His duty: as the light reaches the four directions, he readies the lamp implements and arranges them according to ritual.
The flames must burn brightly, ever radiant.
Should wind or rain prevent the fire from standing firm,
he shall report to the Dharma Master, and only then may the lamps be extinguished.
He must never grow remiss, lest the lamps fail in their duty.

When the number of deputy officers is few, one person may hold two or three positions. When there are many, two or three people may share two positions.

**Deputy Chief Lector Master**
[Rank] [Name] So-and-So
His duty: he assists with the bells and chimes, leading the chanting of ritual affairs. He escorts the Ritual Officer, guiding their bows and movements.

**Deputy Supervisor of the Refrectory Master**
[Rank] [Name] So-and-So
His duty: he assists in conducting altar rites, overseeing the offering of vegetarian meals. He recites the announcements and proclamations, making known the invocations and prayers.

**Deputy Scripture Attendant Master**
[Rank] [Name] So-and-So
His duty: he arranges the altar offerings, presents and pours the libations. He assists in reciting the scriptural divisions, guiding the spirits in their ceremonial approach.

**Deputy Incense Attendant Master**
[Rank] [Name] So-and-So
His duty: he tends to the censers and vessels, assists in adding incense sticks, holds the hand censer, and aids in the rites of the Dao.

**Deputy Lamp Attendant Master**
[Rank] [Name] So-and-So
His duty: he prepares the lamp implements, adds oil and wicks, and ensures the light continues unbroken from dusk till dawn—only then is he deemed fit for his post.

This notice is hereby posted. Each is to purify the heart and still the mind, contemplating the divine and focusing on the true. Be attentive and clear in all communications, maintaining solemnity in ascent and descent. May the Celestial Perfected descend in response, and both the hidden and manifest realms receive blessings. Let the Five Emperors’ assessment of merit proceed without fault, and the Three Officials’ records remain unblemished.

These regulations are clearly set forth—take care not to neglect or disobey them. This announcement is hereby made, and all are to uphold their duties.

Thus posted.
On the ___ day of the ___ month of the ___ year.
[Rank] [Name] So-and-So, seal affixed.

**Notice to Constrain Wandering Spirits**
**Supreme Yellow Register Great Vegetarian Altar**

This altar is now established by the honorable [Name] of [Place] to conduct the Supreme Yellow Register Great Vegetarian Ritual, primarily for the deliverance of the deceased kin [Name] and universally for all wandering spirits in attendance, as well as the six paths of rebirth and the four kinds of life—all orphaned souls and stagnant spirits—to ascend to the immortal realms. As the ritual altar is now constructed, the marshals, officers, and deities such as the City God and local earth gods are summoned to guard and protect the altar. The following constraints are hereby decreed:

This notice is to inform all divine officers of the Dharma Courts, celestial marshals, spirit officials, courier deities, divine soldiers, mounted messengers, the City God of this locale, local earth gods, Controller of Destiny, and all attendant guardian deities of the matters herein. Each is to unite in heart and strength to safeguard the altar grounds. Sweep away defilements and impure qi, reverently welcome the divine chariots. Ensure unimpeded communication of prayers and summons. Gather all wandering spirits under the jurisdiction of the yin officials, along with the river-sands of orphaned and stagnant souls, in the vicinity to await the ritual summons. Let them promptly attend the altar to bathe, refine, and be delivered. Let them hear the scriptures and receive the Dharma, accept precepts and transmit talismans. May they clearly comprehend their meritorious deeds and ascend to the pure realms.

Should there be karmic creditors, vengeful foes, or those who, in life, were thieves, malefactors, or oppressors of ritual offerings—those who consume meat, drink alcohol, or violate altar prohibitions—let them be silently restrained and subdued, their retribution made manifest. Ensure the ritual’s merit is perfectly fulfilled and demonic obstacles do not arise. May the state and household receive blessings, and both the living and the dead be delivered. Upon completion, report merits for promotion and reward, in gratitude for divine favor.

This notice is hereby proclaimed for all to know and abide.
Thus posted.
On the ___ day of the ___ month of the ___ year.

**Proclamation to Admonish Wandering Spirits**
**Supreme Yellow Register Great Vegetarian Altar**

This altar, on behalf of the sponsor of the Yellow Register Great Ritual, the honorable [Name], has erected the Supreme Yellow Register Great Vegetarian Ritual. On the night of the ___ day of this month, an unbounded measure of food will be offered in the nighttime ritual.

All spirits summoned to the Dharma assembly—those of the six paths and four kinds of life, the nine provinces and ten classes, the river-sands of stagnant souls, and the suffering spirits of the dark night—whether male or female, old or young, must consider this: there may be creditors from past lives, ancient grudges, debts of life, wealth, kindness, or virtue. At this juncture, evil thoughts may suddenly arise. Instead of seeking liberation, they may harbor thoughts of revenge. Such intentions will prevent transcendence and perpetuate the cycle of rebirth. Therefore, the following constraints are decreed:

This notice is to admonish all spirits summoned to the Dharma assembly—those of the five directions and five clans, civil and martial, scholars and Daoist adepts, lay devotees and monastics, female Daoists and nuns, farmers and scribes, soldiers and officers, merchants and artisans, diviners and shamans, servants and physicians, the orphaned and widowed, those who died unjustly or violently, executed rebels, the unfilial struck by lightning, the deformed and disabled, the blind and deaf, those who died in childbirth or infancy, creditors and debtors, those who perished in grass or ruins, spirits of ancient altars and abandoned shrines—whether male or female, old or young, all orphaned souls, stagnant spirits, prisoners of the long night, and divine or ghostly multitudes without refuge or master.

Each must restrain body and spirit, listen to the scriptures and the Dharma. Assemble in order and partake of the offerings. Do not bully the weak, nor rely on strength to intimidate the timid. Let all be sated, and fairness prevail. Wash and purify body and mind, follow the true Dao. Reconcile with foes, repent of transgressions. Through the merit of these teachings and the fruits of this deliverance, together seek liberation and aspire to rebirth. Do not linger in delusion or cling to the ghostly realm. Be reverent and await transcendence. The covenants of the Perfected and the ritual codes carry the gravest prohibitions. All must comply and not violate them.

Thus proclaimed.
On the ___ day of the ___ month of the ___ year.
[Rank] [Name] So-and-So, seal affixed.

**Proclamation to Instruct Wandering Spirits**
**Supreme Yellow Register Great Vegetarian Altar**

Previously, this altar received a petition from the honorable [Name], who sought to conduct the Supreme Yellow Register Great Vegetarian Ritual to deliver the deceased kin [Name] and universally deliver all wandering spirits in attendance. All spirits now summoned to the altar for deliverance have already purified body and spirit and paid homage at the altar. Daily, they are guided in timely rituals to venerate the sagely Perfected, reverently listen to the Dharma, and await deliverance. The following further admonitions are hereby decreed:

This notice specially commissions the altar supervisors, courier deities of the Dharma Courts, and spirit marshals to constantly exhort the summoned spirits—those delivered at the altar and those bound by karmic enmity—to each generate good thoughts, abandon evil affinities, restrain body and mind, and take refuge in the Dao’s fruits. Recognize past lives and cease forming grudges. Know that the nature received at birth is inherently pure. Yet, deluded by sensory conditions, false passions arise. Clinging to these evil roots creates obstacles and afflictions. When qi withers and spirit departs, the original state is difficult to restore. The five hindrances entangle, and the three paths exact retribution. Forever sunk in the dark night, fallen into evil origins, drowned in delusive waves, unable to escape.

Such suffering has already been endured in the past. Now, standing before the Dao, seek the Dharma of liberation. Sever inverted thoughts. Arouse faith and turn toward the heart. Reflect on the original nature. Ultimately, emptiness reveals the true, and the actual nature of sin and obstacles is also empty. Thus, the wondrous function appears before you, and the numinous light remains undimmed. Roam freely and at ease, forever freed from the cycle of rebirth.

Reverently await the altar’s timely guidance. Venerate the sagely Perfected, repent of transgressions. Receive precepts and talismans to rely upon for deliverance. Do not leave the spirit assembly without summons, nor depart at improper times. The codes of the Perfected are clear, and the prohibitions are most severe. All must comply and not violate them.

Thus proclaimed.
On the ___ day of the ___ month of the ___ year.
[Rank] [Name] So-and-So, seal affixed.

**Notice of Ritual Sequence**
**Supreme Yellow Register Great Vegetarian Altar**

**Notice of Ritual Sequence**
**Supreme Yellow Register Great Vegetarian Altar**

This altar, in accordance with the petition submitted by the official So-and-So of such-and-such rank, hereby conducts a three-day Supreme Yellow Register Great Vegetarian Ritual at [location] Daoist temple or abbey, on behalf of the deceased relative So-and-So and all souls gathered in assembly. Memorials shall be presented, and talismanic decrees proclaimed. The sublime model shall be widely honored, and all shall be aided in ascension. Upon completion, the merits of the memorials shall be declared, and the Dragon Tablet and petitions offered. A pure offering of three hundred and sixty divine positions shall be reverently performed to express profound gratitude for boundless grace.

All Daoist participants in the ritual, aside from those already assigned duties in accordance with the codes, must attend to their roles with care. To prevent omissions or errors during the proceedings, the sequence of rites is hereby listed as follows:

**First Day:**
Dispatch preliminary announcements
Raise the ritual banner
Begin the recitation of scriptures

**Second Day:**
Dispatch the formal memorials

**Third Day:**
Present and prostrate before the memorials to the Celestial Officials, as listed by day and division

**Midday of the Third Day:**
Deliver the ordination address
Initiate the covenant
Erect the ritual canopy
Purify the altar and issue the jade missives
At dusk:
Distribute the lamps
Consecrate the altar and lodge the nightly invocation
Recite the precepts
Appoint supplementary officers
Proclaim the prohibitions

**In the stillness of night:** [rites continue]

**Remaining Night of the Ritual Lamps:**
Summon the spirits
Bathe in purification
Pay homage to the Perfected
Recite the incantation over the offerings

**First Day at Dawn:**
Perform the formal fast and circumambulate the Dao
Recite the scriptures

**Midday:**
Perform the formal fast and circumambulate the Dao as at dawn, omitting the proclamation of the *Weiling* incantation and the procession of officials
Recite the scriptures

**At Dusk:**
Perform the formal fast and circumambulate the Dao as at midday

**In the Stillness of Night:**
Invoke the Nine Prisons, dispatch talismans, and break open the prisons
Extol the lamps of the Nine Dark Realms
Confess and revolve the Wheel of Radiance lamps

**Second Day at Dawn:**
Perform the formal fast and circumambulate the Dao as on the first day at dawn, omitting the procession of officials
Recite the scriptures

**Midday:**
Perform the formal fast and circumambulate the Dao as on the first day at midday
Recite the scriptures

**At Dusk:**
Perform the formal fast and circumambulate the Dao as on the first day at dusk

**In the Stillness of Night:**
Summon all wandering souls and perform the *Hulu* refinement rites

**Third Day at Dawn:**
Perform the formal fast and circumambulate the Dao as on the second day at dawn
Recite the scriptures

**Midday:**
Perform the formal fast and circumambulate the Dao as on the second day at midday
Recite the scriptures

**At Dusk:**
Perform the formal fast, circumambulate the Dao, and prostrate in homage
Present the memorial for the ascension of the Celestial Officials

**In the Stillness of Night:**
Erect the Water and Fire Ponds and perform the Great Refinement for the ascension of the departed souls

**Fourth Day:**
Dismantle the altar, prostrate, and submit the memorials
Deposit the Three Tallies

**Fifth Day:**
Hold the Offering Rite

**Above follows the order of hymns and chants as listed in sequence. The right-hand notice shall be duly proclaimed and sung in harmony. Ascents and descents must be performed with dignity, and the sequence must not be disordered, that the sacred and true may witness, and both the hidden and manifest receive blessing. The altar has its established rules—each must uphold their duty. Thus the notice is posted.**
