**The Second Precept:** Uphold benevolence, refrain from killing, and compassionately aid all beings. Extend loving-kindness and universal salvation to all.

**The Third Precept:** Maintain integrity and yield to righteousness; neither lust nor steal. Constantly cultivate virtuous thoughts and sacrifice for others.

**The Fourth Precept:** Be free from lust and desire; let the heart not wander. Uphold purity and vigilance, ensuring conduct remains unstained.

**The Fifth Precept:** Let speech be free of malice; words should not be ornate or deceitful. Be upright within and without, avoiding verbal transgressions.

**The Sixth Precept:** Abstain from alcohol and regulate conduct, harmonizing qi and temperament. Do not injure the spirit or commit manifold evils.

**The Seventh Precept:** Do not envy others’ superiority or contend for fame and merit. In all matters, yield and defer, humbling yourself to deliver others.

**The Eighth Precept:** Do not criticize scriptures and teachings or slander sacred texts. Receive the Dharma with reverence, ever as if in the presence of the divine.

**The Ninth Precept:** Do not engage in quarrels or disputes, nor judge the four classes of beings. Heavenly beings and humans will resent and blame you, harming your spirit and qi.

**The Tenth Precept:** In all actions and undertakings, maintain equanimity and single-mindedness. Let harmony prevail among people and serenity among spirits, ever thus in conduct.

The Celestial Worthy declared: "Those who cultivate and uphold these pure precepts align with the heart of Heaven. Constantly practice great compassion, vowing to universally deliver this troubled world. Reverently follow the sacred teachings without negligence. Better to die upholding goodness than to live in evil. Through unwavering devotion, one may be delivered from the Five Paths and avoid the Three Evil Realms. Protected by all heavens and revered by myriad spirits, those who maintain long fasts and uphold precepts will naturally attain deliverance from the world."

The Celestial Worthy said: "The Dao is venerable, the Dharma is wondrous, and the human body is also precious. Thus, the Dao has revealed scriptures and precepts to deliver humanity. Once the human body is delivered, it ascends to unite with the Dao. Cultivate purity, observe fasts, and uphold precepts. Calm the heart, still the mind, and let aspirations be clear. Single-mindedly turn toward the Dao, focusing without distraction. Purify the six viscera, avoid flavors beyond moderation. Maintain inner and outer clarity and emptiness, ever in accord with the natural. On the day of the fast, express all vows. If sincere, they will ascend, and the Four Heavenly Patrollers and Ten Divisions of Mighty Spirits will descend to witness. They observe and listen to the sacred sounds, reflecting upon your heart. Those who uphold precepts and practice the Dao will have their merits recorded in the heavens, and karmic retribution will swiftly manifest. The Dao does not fail those who diligently practice and earnestly receive its teachings—do not let demonic words deceive you."

The Celestial Worthy said: "When establishing fasts and practicing the Dao, the Four Heavenly Kings arrive in flying dragon chariots and jade carriages of eight scenes. Attended by perfected beings and jade maidens, holding flower banners, leading with phoenix songs, followed by celestial music, white cranes and lions, their harmonious chants fill the air. They burn incense, scatter flowers, and float through the void to come. They gaze upon the rites, observe the procession, and listen to the Dharma-sound. The Heavenly Kings descend, and myriad spirits pay homage. How can one not fully adhere to these methods? First receive the Ten Precepts, then practice the Dao. Proceed with refined steps, calm the heart, and close the mind. In sitting, rising, lying, and resting, never depart from proper decorum. The Heavenly Kings will rejoice, and your name will be inscribed in the Upper Clarity. This is what it means to attain the Dao within the square inch of the heart."

**Hymns of Upholding Precepts with Exegesis**

The Dao is the origin of formlessness,
The field of merit for all.
Establishing merit has no fixed master,
For each person’s vows arise from within.
Emptying oneself to respond to beings,
Focus the heart without partiality.
The Great Sage expounds the supreme teaching,
Like rain descending from heaven.
Lofty peaks are universally embraced,
While humility forms the abyss.
The sea is king of all rivers,
For it can relinquish even the dragon’s scales.
Through ten thousand kalpas, preserve wisdom’s use,
Not merely for this lifetime.
Uphold precepts without the slightest lapse,
And life after life, good affinities will form.
Profoundly contemplate the Great Vehicle,
And you shall embody the true Dao.

*Composed by the Perfected of the Great Ultimate, from the* Scripture of the Numinous Treasure on the Questions of the Immortal Duke. *After the precepts are expounded, circumambulate while chanting.*

**Exegesis on Filling Offices**

According to the *True Immortal Ranks of the Golden Register of the Upper Prime* in the *Simplified Writs of the Numinous Treasure*: For the rites of the fast, on the eve, appoint the High Master of Ritual, the Master of Recitation, one Supervisor of the Fast, one Attendant of Scriptures, one Attendant of Incense, and one Attendant of Lamps. On the morrow, they shall each perform their designated duties during the procession.

From the *Simplified Writs of the Golden Register*, only four of the same Dharma are to be invited: one Supervisor of the Fast, one Attendant of Affairs, one Attendant of Incense, and one Attendant of Lamps. At the main gate, they shall follow the master in circumambulation, bowing to the host to pray for the absolution of sins and mutual deliverance. Thus, beyond the six offices, no other titles exist.

Though the *Ritual Codes of Zhang Qingdu* speak of "fast officials" numbering from six to eighteen, it does not specify their respective duties. The intent of conducting a fast and circumambulating the Dao is fulfilled with the six offices alone. The remaining officials are all assigned to assist the six, jointly managing the fast. Hence, the *Simplified Writs of the Golden Register* state: "In ascending or descending the fast, precedence is given to office. Among those of equal office, precedence is given to seniority in years. Among those of equal years, precedence is given to virtue." The hierarchy of the six offices is already fixed in order. If there is but one person, no office is established. The principle that "among equals, precedence is given to seniority" is broadly evident here.

Moreover, the *Scripture of the Great Mystery* states: For those who transmit the Dao and its methods before a fast, the limit is thirty-eight persons; the minimum may not be fewer than six. Fast durations are nine, seven, five, or three days. To reduce it by even a single day is to hold a gathering, not a fast. The thirty-eight persons are as follows: first, the Three Masters—one Principal Master and two Protecting Masters, who are the Dharma Masters; second, the Five Guarantors, five persons who are the Masters of Recitation; third, the Six Illuminators, six persons who are the Supervisors of the Fast; fourth, the Seven Witnesses, seven persons who are the Attendants of Scriptures; fifth, the Eight Degrees, eight persons who are the Attendants of the Master; sixth, the Nine Accomplishments, nine persons who are the Attendants of Lamps. Thus, in the nine-tiered altar circumambulation rites recorded in the canon, the six offices are filled by more than one person, following this principle.

In recent times, beyond the High Master of Ritual, the remaining officials each don ritual vestments and occupy their positions. New titles such as Keeper of the Bell, Attendant of the Chime Stone, Announcer, and Attendant of the Altar have been created to substitute for the duties of the assembled officials. Beyond the six offices, many superfluous titles have arisen. Yet do they not know that the *Ritual Codes* clearly state: "Those conducting the fast wear coarse robes; those reciting scriptures wear ritual stoles"? The essence of the fast lies in sincerity and repentance. The utmost reverence is required to achieve spiritual resonance—how can it be a matter of mere display?

Master Du Guangcheng has discussed this in detail; his words are appended below.

**Master Du Guangcheng states:**
The scriptures and ritual codes all declare that among the fast officials, the one of highest virtue and power serves as the Dharma Master, while the one most versed in ritual procedures serves as the Master of Recitation. The *Duties of the Master of Recitation* further state: "First strike the Dharma drum, then lead the assembly. Set the wind to order and ritual, relying on their guidance and recitation." Thus, chanting, singing, and leading the procession are all the duties of the Master of Recitation.

In Wu, Jiangbiao, and Jingchu, the Master of Recitation holds the chime stone and chants the liturgy during the circumambulation. "First strike the Dharma drum" refers to the bell and chime stone. To ensure the officials are solemn and the ritual dignified, the chime stone must first be struck to align the assembly, after which the Master of Recitation chants the ascent to the altar—this too is the duty of the Master of Recitation.

However, in recent years, if the Master of Recitation is advanced in years or virtue and does not wish to be burdened with every task, one person from among the officials may be appointed to hold the chime stone and chant the liturgy. This is a temporary measure, not an ancient institution. Upon examination, it is a neglect of duty. Furthermore, some later students, acting on whim, have arbitrarily added an "Attendant of the Chime Stone" beyond the six offices, with no scriptural basis—such errors run deep.

The High Master of Ritual is responsible for making offerings and petitions, leading the assembly in all movements. If infirmity or age renders one unfit, one may retire. How can one delegate duties, becoming a mere supernumerary? Yet in Shu, the High Master of Ritual only announces the opening and closing of the incense burner, declaring his name and title. All other proclamations are entrusted to others. Though it is said that he leads the chant and others follow, how is this different from a dragon’s roar answered by a turtle’s croak? Such actions invite karmic retribution and self-inflicted blame. If even human affairs cannot tolerate this, how can the Dao of Heaven respond? Future Dharma leaders must take heed: do not seek convenience in the present only to accumulate sins for the hereafter.

The Supervisor of the Fast upholds the ritual codes and corrects transgressions. Impartiality is essential to jointly uphold the canonical laws. If any violations occur, the offender must be formally admonished. The one receiving punishment must willingly accept the penalty. The hope is that externally, ritual propriety is maintained to preserve the dignity of the salvific rite; internally, the heart remains unbetrayed, avoiding the regret of unfulfilled aspirations. During admonishment, there must be no clamor or dispute. The one upholding the law must proceed with proper protocol; the one at fault must not resist or refuse. Such conduct not only offends the sages but also invites ridicule from the assembly.

Next, the Attendant of Scriptures arranges the altar, presides over the Dharma seat, and oversees the scripture tables, offerings, and ritual implements, ensuring all is properly displayed. Moreover, the old method placed two high seats within the fast hall for recitation at the three periods. Thus, the *Simplified Writs* state: "Recitation occurs at the three periods." The *Duties* further state: "Guard the two lion seats." The *Penalty Codes* state: "Those listening to scriptures who lean or sit improperly without holding the ritual tablet," and "Those who ask improper questions." These all indicate that after the circumambulation, the Dharma Master and officials engage in recitation at the three periods.

In recent times, the practice has been to circumambulate and recite scriptures at the three periods within the altar space, with no recitation or two high seats. During scripture recitation, the officials sit while one person distributes purifying water, the Attendant of Incense offers incense, and the Attendant of Scriptures recites. After the recitation, the Attendant of Scriptures collects the scriptures, returns them to their seats, and tidies the altar, ensuring the offerings are properly maintained and no outsiders trespass upon the sacred space. These are the duties of the Attendant of Scriptures.

Do not neglect one’s duties with empty attendance, nor display arrogance and irreverence. Do not allow tables and stands to lie askew within the altar space, nor let offerings become soiled or mixed with impurities. Do not permit servants or kitchen staff to enter the altar, lest they profane the divine and true, violating prohibitions and precepts. Even after the altar’s closure, one must not permit reverse movement, yet servants and cooks are often allowed to enter and exit freely—such practices are common and must be strictly forbidden. Should they persist, the Attendant of Scriptures shall bear the blame and punishment.

The duties of the Attendant of Incense are fully set forth in the ritual writ. Yet in recent times, many have grown lax and negligent, so that not only does the incense smoke often cease, but the fire may go out and the ashes grow cold. Moreover, before the High Priest has even ascended the altar, some presume to add incense and tend the censer within the sacred space—such violations are widespread. When reviewing the ritual codes, one must take heed and exercise caution.

The Attendant of Lamps must be diligent and vigilant, ensuring the lamps are tended according to ritual, extinguished at dawn, and relit to sustain their brightness—only then is one deemed fit for the role. Yet of late, some unlearned and shallow-minded individuals, instead of entrusting the Attendant of Scriptures with the arrangement of the altar, have established a separate post called the "Altar Attendant." This introduces redundant titles beyond the six established offices. Enlightened Dharma Masters should reject such innovations, lest they leave false traces and become a laughingstock to later generations.

Furthermore, according to the ancient statutes of the *Golden Register* and the old rites of the *Yellow Register*, on the eve of the pre-dawn invocation and during the declaration of merit, one must first perform the *Natural Audience* before proceeding with the ritual. Thus, the *Rites of Invocation and Purification* state: "The officials shall lead one another in first performing the *Natural Audience*; after the Three Bows, they shall report to the Purification Office, recite the precepts, and proclaim the ritual codes. At dawn the following morning, they shall proceed with the ritual in accordance with the Dao." This method has been transmitted from Master Lu of the Celestial Master, Celestial Master Kou, and Zhang Qingdu, down to the present day, spanning many generations. As the *Purification Rites* derive from the *Numinous Treasure*, the *Natural Audience* is the origin of all purification—thus, it is performed first to demonstrate that one has not forgotten the root.

Yet some ignorant Daoists, failing to grasp the intent of the ancient worthies, first appoint the six offices before the Mystic Master, proclaim the ritual codes, and receive the tablets—only then do they ascend the altar. They claim that Master Jianji’s purification rites are erroneous, adorning falsehoods and slandering the teachings, their words and reasoning confused and ignorant to the extreme. Even worse, some of their followers imitate these practices. Such actions not only disrupt the Dharma but also incur the sin of slandering the worthy. Those of discernment in the teachings should firmly reject them.

Among the old rites, there is one transmitted error: during the pre-dawn invocation and declaration of merit, the *Natural Audience* should properly address the *Numinous Treasure Celestial Worthy*. Yet the transmitted practice has been to bow to titles such as the *Jade Treasure Sovereign*, which slightly deviates from the original intent of the *Natural Audience*. This may be due to the passage of time and textual corruption. In the present ritual, this has been corrected—not out of presumption, but in accordance with reason. May later scholars of the age and future worthies uphold this together.

The *Numinous Treasure Purification Rites* are fully recorded in the *Ten Sections of the Flying Celestial Wondrous Scriptures*. Their invocations, vows, repentances, and prayers, as well as the postures of reverence, the protocols of ascent and descent, are all ancient texts from the Dragon Han era and must not be altered. Only Dharma Masters who have mastered the Three Caverns, received the scriptures and registers, and are well-versed in ritual procedures may preside over them. Thus, in Zhang Qingdu’s *Rites of Construction and Establishment*, one bows only to the *Primordial Chapter of Invocation* and the memorial—local deities and spirits are not petitioned separately. This is because the purification rites are profound and subtle: the divine officials and celestial soldiers respond to the words themselves, requiring no relay of documents or messengers to achieve resonance.

The *Numinous Treasure Great Dharma* descended to the world, and with it came the texts of jade talismans and golden tablets, the registers of true writs, the incantations for summoning divine tigers, the rites of refinement and deliverance of Nanchang, the ablutions of the Five Immortals, the protocols of radiance and descending light, the methods of staff-breaking and prison-breaking, and the gates of repentance through wheel lamps. Each has its own secrets, and each is performed in proper sequence. They elevate the sinful and deliver both the living and the dead, refining the ancient methods with greater detail. The ancient methods focused solely on purification, recitation, and lecture, without other distractions, so their structure was simple and direct. In the present age, grand purifications are often accompanied by multiple rites, resulting in a proliferation of details. Though the needs of past and present differ, each has its proper place. One must seek the root to understand the purpose.

The proper purification rites of invocation and thanksgiving, the pre-dawn invocation, and the dispersal of the altar are based on the scriptural texts. The issuance of talismanic commands, the summoning and refinement of spirits, and the deliverance of souls derive from the *Numinous Treasure*. The bowing to memorials, the elevation of the sinful, and the liberation of the damned originate from the *Orthodox Unity*. If one thoroughly investigates their origins and ends, their application will not be in vain.

Those who do not conform should seek like-minded companions, select an auspicious site, establish an altar, and adhere strictly to the scriptural texts, without incorporating extraneous rites. I know that the eyes of the Dao observe all—such merit is towering and cannot be measured by shallow standards. Yet without a scholar who has mastered the Three Caverns and the highest learning, one cannot advance in this.

**Proclamation of Prohibitions**
The present regulations state: The *Thirty-Six Prohibitions* derive from the *Ritual of the Supreme Ultimate’s Purification*. They are to be made of ivory, bone, bamboo, or wood—thirty-six tablets in total, each eight *fen* wide and nine *cun* tall, inscribed with the text in a manner similar to the ritual tablets. Zhang Qingdu said: "On the day of the circumambulation, they are placed upon the ritual table." Du Guangcheng said: "They are stored in a crimson pouch, and the Purification Supervisor carries them when ascending the altar. If a violation occurs, the tablet is presented as a penalty." Both methods are acceptable.

Zhang Qingdu said: "Those whose bodies bear the weight of grave transgressions—even they are permitted to seek redemption through purification and repentance, thereby dissolving their offenses. Now, the rites of purification elevate reverence through prostration; how much more should this apply to those of lofty virtue? Yet when ritual protocols falter, I propose substituting prostrations in their place, with the number of bows determined by the severity of the matter. The officiating officers shall adjudicate accordingly in the moment—this aligns with the intent of Lu Jianji. Furthermore, the *Thirty-Six Prohibitions* are also recorded in the *Laws of the Supreme Ultimate and Mysterious Capital*. There, the penalties are inscribed in fragrant oil, totaling only thirty clauses. That it speaks of *Thirty-Six Prohibitions* likely accounts for the host’s duties in sweeping and cleansing the hall, the Daoists’ bearing of towels, robes, tablets, and shoes, and the reporting to the Purification Supervisor—along with violations of decorum by those below or above the dais, or lapses in ritual propriety. These, combined with the preceding prohibitions, make thirty-six in all. However, the six additional clauses, though listed as prohibitions, carry no penalty of fragrant-oil inscription and thus seem unfit for tablets. Yet Zhang Qingdu states that the tablets—thirty-six in number, made of bamboo, wood, ivory, or bone—are to be inscribed individually for each prohibition, from the High Master downward. This essentially consolidates the tablets for the six offices into a single set.

**Reopening the Censer**
After the announcements conclude, approach the altar, offer incense, and recite the invocations. Drawn from the *Scripture of the Natural Rites of the Three Registers of Numinous Treasure*.

*Concluded: Scroll Thirty-Three of the* Instantiated Rites of the Supreme Yellow Register Great Purification
*Scroll Thirty-Four of the* Instantiated Rites of the Supreme Yellow Register Great Purification

Compiled by Jiang Shuyu, Transmitted Master of Enforcement of the Most High and Disciple of the Perfected Immortal Liu Yongguang, the Serene Master of the Three Caverns

**Section on Purification Rites and Their Application**
**Explanation of the Announcement of Official Departure**

Master Zhang Wanfu the Celestial Master states: All transmitted words and courier dispatches rely upon the spirit-way to achieve resonance and communion. By "spirit-way," the ranks of immortal officials, clerks, and soldiers are meant. These immortal officials, clerks, and soldiers must be received through one’s master—namely, the registers of the numinous governance of immortals, the Three Divisions and Eight Effulgences, the Thirty-Two Heavens, the Jade Lads and Jade Maidens, and the Direct Talismans and Direct Officers of the Five Thearchs. Only when a Daoist possesses these immortal officials may they participate in the invitation to the fast. To perform rites in vain, without the presence of true numina, is to incur fault and punishment. Beware.

After the censer is opened, all officials kneel in unison. The Dharma Master strikes the teeth twenty-four times and summons the clerks and soldiers. Once the supplication to the heavens is complete, each strikes the teeth three times and swallows saliva three times.

*Recorded in the* Scripture of the Celestial Guest’s Supreme Ultimate Rites for the Presentation of the Fast’s Dignified Observances.

Master Xian the Immortal Duke states: This is called the rite for the initial fast’s supplication. At the six daily periods of burning incense, one need only pray toward the censer and then perform the prostrations.

Zhang Qingdu says: When establishing a fast, only one official is summoned. Upon the fast’s conclusion and the declaration of merit, the clerks and soldiers are no longer summoned.

**Explanation of the Supplication and Aspiration Recitation**
During the main fast, when supplicating the sacred ranks and subsequent invocations, the text is drawn from the *Alliance with the Perfected: Ordinances of the Numinous Treasure*, as spoken by the Flying Celestial Divine Beings.

The three offerings of incense and the recitation of manifest aspirations are taken from the *Register of Immortal Transcendents of the Lower Prime Yellow Register*. In present practice, when burning incense, the phrases from "I take refuge in the Master, the Venerable, the Great Sages, and the host of immortals" to "uniting with the Dao and the Perfected" are standard in the texts for the three offerings of incense during all fasts. Moreover, in current ordinances, after the supplication, the phrase "uniting with the Dao and the Perfected" is also used. This is because the *Register of Immortal Transcendents of the Yellow Register Scripture* includes this passage before the aspiration recitation for the three pinches of incense. Not daring to alter the language of the scriptures, Zhang Qingdu’s ordinances follow suit. This is briefly explained for the benefit of later learners who may not know its origin.

**Explanation of the Repentance to the Twenty Directions**
Following the directions and ordinances, repentance is offered to the Palace of the Sun in the northeast, the Palace of the Moon in the Central Marchmount, the Palace of the Stars in the southwest, the Water Palace, the Scriptures and Methods in the north, and the Four Marchmounts, each according to its respective direction.

*These repentance texts for the twenty directions serve as the dignified observances for the deliverance from the roots of transgression. Drawn from the* Register of Immortal Transcendents of the Lower Prime Yellow Register.

**Explanation of the Visualization of the Nine-Colored Circular Image, the Swallowing of Saliva, and the Commanding of Demons**
The High Functionary stands above the Ghost Gate, the General Lecturer above the Heavenly Gate, and the assembled officials stand in order behind the General Lecturer. First, they strike the teeth three times and swallow saliva three times. In the mind, they visualize the sun and moon before their face, entering through the nostrils into the Cavern Chamber of the Golden Flower Palace between the eyebrows, then proceeding one inch inward to the Palace of the Hall of Light, two inches to the Palace of the Cavern Chamber, and three inches to the Palace of the Cinnabar Field. North of the Hall of Light and south of the Cavern Chamber, one inch upward lies the Palace of the Golden Flower. The sun enters through the left nostril, the moon through the right. Radiance emerges from the back of the neck, resplendently forming a nine-colored circular image that penetrates the Jade Pillow and illuminates the ten directions. They follow this visualization while circumambulating the scriptures.

Again, they strike the teeth three times and swallow saliva three times.

*Recorded in the* Hidden Commentary on the Jade Scripture of the Most High.

**Secret Mantras and Their Explanation**
Master Du Guangcheng states: These secret mantras must not be heard by the ears. To violate this incurs blame and responsibility. Be earnest, be vigilant.

Within the Yellow Center, strategize qi to sever demonic remnants; secretly refine and strengthen essence to sever the old fiend. The Most High issues a decree from the Chamber of the Most High, urgently summoning the Northern Emperor to the Five Palaces. Receiving the majestic command, he proclaims it to the demon kings—fivefold qi billows thickly, clashing with fate. The secret jade scriptures have just flourished in abundance; the Three Heavens revolve in brightness, the Six Heavens complete their cycle. How wise is this!

*Recorded in the* Numinous Treasure Scripture of the Five Talismans and the Human-Bird.

The method of visualization for the Eight Dao Command Registers in the *Cavern-Real* differs from this and is appended below for concurrent use.

When the ritual in each direction is complete, turn back to face east. Visualize the gods with eyes closed, strike the teeth five times, and swallow saliva five times. Envision the five spirits fully present within the body, the five talismans resplendent inside and out, while the demon hordes of the five directions flee far away. Those who come to attend and guard stand in solemn array behind the perfected officials.

After a long while, swallow saliva three times, strike the teeth three times, and recite the incantation from the *Human-Bird Mountain Scripture*: *"Within the Yellow Center, strategize qi..."*

Master Zhang Wanfu the Celestial Master states: Before the Heavenly Worthy expounded the scriptures, the demon kings of the Three Realms and the myriad heavens, along with the five great demon emperors, were all revered as lords of the ten thousand spirits, commanding ghostly legions to roam the vast heavens. They styled themselves as radiant and mighty, their achievements rivaling Heaven. Wielding power and unleashing poison, they afflicted the multitudes with suffering. Men and women offered prayers and sacrifices, slaughtering and dancing to honor and fear them.

After the Heavenly Worthy expounded the scriptures, the hundred demons submitted and transformed. The divine lords received their mandate to universally sweep away inauspiciousness. Demons dared not trespass, ghosts harbored no malevolent spirits. Once the demon multitudes submitted to the Heavenly Worthy, the sagely transformation elevated them to become the exalted sages of the myriad heavens and perfected beings of wondrous conduct. They now drive the chariot ahead, sweeping away dust to clear the path. Thus, when the host of sages wishes to traverse the heavens, they first command the demons to drive the chariot ahead. As the scripture says, *"The demon kings respectfully receive their duties and thereby ascend to the heavens."* Such is the case.

Therefore, when pacing the void, one must first visualize and command the demons.

The three morning audiences commanding the demons, as expounded by Zhang of the Pure Capital, are exhaustive. Master Zhao Daosheng, in his *Huanglu Rituals*, held that inner affairs conclude with the noon audience commanding demons, following the *Jinlu* of the Zhenghe era. This is his mistaken view, not the intent of the scriptures.

*Explanation of pacing the void and circumambulation.*

Master Zhang Wanfu the Heavenly Master states: The Jade Capital Mountain of the Mystic Metropolis crowns the eight directions. It is the domain governed by the Supreme Venerable Sovereign of the Limitless Dao, the August Lord of the Void, and the celestial abode of the loftiest immortals. Here, the great sages of the heavens and the perfected immortals of high rank each observe the fasts and uphold the precepts, revering the Supreme Void Sovereign. On every fast day, they ascend in flying-dragon carriages drawn by the eight-scene cloud chariots, convening in grand assembly at the Jade Capital of the Mystic Metropolis. They burn the naturally fragrant *zhantan* and the life-restoring *lingxiang* incense, while flying immortals scatter blossoms, circumambulating the seven-jeweled terrace thrice as they recite the hymns of the *Kongdong* odes. At that moment, the eight winds unfurl banners, and fragrant flowers drift and disperse. Wafting smoke billows thickly, and the Supreme Venerable praises their virtue. Moreover, the flying deities of heaven, ever riding carriages of azure radiance, roam the Jade Prosperity Heaven. Thrice daily, they lead the host of celestial sages to ascend and pay homage at the seven-jeweled palace, the seven-jeweled terrace, and the seven-jeweled jade palace—all abodes of the Celestial Venerable of Primordial Beginning. As the celestial host pays homage, they circumambulate in procession, chanting the *Dong* hymns, ascending in the *Xuan Bu Xu* odes, or rotating through the void in the *Xuan Kong* hymns, such as the *Great Brahma Immeasurable Dong* and their kind. When the secret incantations conclude, the *doujiang* intones the *Bu Xu* circumambulation, and the assembly proceeds in orderly leftward procession, encircling the scripture three times. For the first hymn, they stand upright, facing the scripture and its image. At the second hymn, they begin the circumambulation. By the tenth hymn, each must return to their original position to conclude. Each time the Supreme Venerable praises them, they turn to face the center, scatter blossoms, and bow once, enacting the rite of the ten directions’ homage to the Mystic Metropolis.

As recorded in the *Upper Prime Golden Register* under the *True Immortals* section: After delivering beings from the cycle of birth and death and establishing the fast’s majestic rites, the homage to the ten directions concludes. Then, for one period, they circumambulate leftward around the incense and lamps three times. The master recites the *Bu Xu* hymns, while the disciples at the gate chant the praises thrice, following the *Xuantai* method. Superior and subordinate proceed in sequence, moving with serene and graceful steps, modulating their voices and rectifying their qi as they chant the *Kongdong* hymns. They must not glance about, lest their thoughts wander, nor falter in pace or err in order, nor jostle one another in advance or retreat. The number of circumambulations should be adjusted according to the breadth of the altar space. If the altar is narrow, they may scatter blossoms during the second, fifth, and eighth hymns while circumambulating, and for the rest, face the scripture and its image.

The ten *Bu Xu Kongdong* hymns, with annotations:

1.
We bow our heads to the Supreme Venerable,
Burning incense to return to the Void.
Luminous radiance follows our turning,
The Dharma-wheel likewise circles thrice.
Mysterious vows arise in the four quarters,
Spiritual blessings extend to kings and lords.
Seven generations ascend to heaven’s halls,
Resplendent, their glory unfolds.

2.
Whistling and singing, we gaze upon the Great Desert,
Heavenly music delights our joy.
Equal fragrance exalts the supreme virtue,
Lesser immortals cannot compare.
Wondrous thoughts illumine the Mystic Awareness,
In orderly ranks we traverse the void.
Rotating, we tread the cloud’s warp,
Riding the void, we pace the Mystic Record.
Chanting the hymns of the Lord of Unity,
A hundred passages naturally harmonize.
Bending, we command the lads of the eight seas;
Uplifting, we escort the high immortals.
The heavens scatter fragrant blossoms,
Solemnly, the numinous wind arises.
Long-held vows root destiny,
Thus we attain lofty eminence.
Rejoicing before the Supreme Venerable,
Even ten thousand kalpas are but a beginning.

3.
Towering, the Mystic Metropolis Mountain,
The ten directions revere the August One.
Far-flung, the Heavenly Treasure Terrace,
Its radiance outshines the flowing sun.
Resplendent, the five groves of blossoms,
Brilliant, their crimson fruits gleam.
Ever mindful to consume the Mystic Essence,
Refining the fluids to solidify form and substance.
Golden light scatters the Purple Tenuity,
Graceful, the Great Vehicle soars free.
Looking up and down, we contemplate the Supreme Venerable,
The radiant splendor flourishes in the cinnabar field.
Gazing left, we grasp the *Yuyi*;
Glancing right, we embrace the *Jielin*.
The Six Perfections crown the Brahma-conduct,
Virtue and power renew with the sun.
Long-cultivated karmic blessings respond,
Hearing the scriptures as if meeting kin.
Heaven-endowed with talent surpassing the world,
Delighting in reciting the subtle and arcane.
The qi of the Supreme Harmony and the Void,
Exhaling and inhaling the flowing rosy mist.
Embryonic breathing stills the hundred passages,
In profound emptiness, we fathom the three conveniences.
The *Ninao* cavern illumines with bright radiance,
Thus we become the Golden Flower Immortals.

4.
The demon kings respectfully receive their duties,
Thus they ascend to pay homage to the heavens.
All begins with the fasts and precepts,
Accumulating merit to bind past karmic ties.
Soaring through the Great Void,
Escorting the loftiest immortals.
Guiding the reins to the ten directions,
Resting in rotation at the Mystic Radiance’s slope.
Looking up, we behold the Terrace of Kalpa’s Blade;
Looking down, we gaze upon the Purple Cloud Net.
Carefree in the Supreme Venerable’s capital,
Together we sit upon lotus blossoms.
Accumulating learning to become perfected beings,
Tranquil, our *rong* and *wei* harmonize.
Eternally enjoying boundless longevity,
Ten thousand springs are but a trifle.

5.
The Great Dao’s master is the Mystic Quiescence,
Ascending as immortals, friends with the peerless.
The noble scion transmits the numinous talismans,
The Great One bears the *Dong* hymns.
The *sharira* radiates golden splendor,
The dragon-drawn carriage suddenly arrives to welcome.
The Heavenly Venerable gazes upon the cloud chariot,
Floating, floating, riding the void in flight.
Fragrant blossoms like flying snow,
Drifting mists luxuriate upon the Mystic Beam.
Bowing our heads to the Golden Portal,
Hand in hand, we invite one another to the Jade Capital.
The *Qianshu* garden of the round radiance,
Resplendent, the seven-jeweled grove.
Three hundred named heavenly beasts,
Lions vast as ten thousand *xun*.
Flying dragons crouch and roar,
Divine phoenixes chant in rhythm.
The numinous wind fans wondrous blossoms,
Pure fragrance scatters upon our robes.
Without the talent of high immortals,
How could one indulge such a heart?

6.
We array our nine-dragon carriage,
Riding the void in carefree ease.
The eight heavens lie like the palm of a hand,
The six directions—how could they be distant?
The host of immortals recites the *Dong Xuan*,
The Supreme Venerable sings the pure hymn.
Fragrant blossoms scatter with the wind,
Jade tones form in the purple empyrean.
The five sufferings all burst forth,
The eight difficulties follow the scriptures’ emptiness.
Wondrous indeed is the numinous garden,
Raising this great Dharma-bridge.

7.
The Palace of the Heavenly True Lord of Unity,
Lushly crowning the radiant spirits.
Flowing and resplendent, the Dharma-wheel’s warp,
Rotating through the void to enter the formless.
The Void Sovereign strikes the cloud zither,
The host of perfected beings recites the *Dong* scriptures.
The high immortals solemnly praise,
Through endless kalpas, they preserve integrity and purity.
The supremely true await nothing,
At times, they guide the flying dragons.
Long fasts convene at the Mystic Metropolis,
Jade chimes resound with the ringing of chimes.
The ten blossoms gather the host of immortals,
Purple mists congeal to form a palace.
Jeweled canopies array before the Supreme Venerable,
Perfected beings hold lotus blossoms.
Scattering blossoms, we declare our vows,
Grasping the tally, we subdue the demon kings.
Dharma-drums assemble the host of immortals,
Numinous chants harmonize without discord.
There is no "can" or "cannot,"
Thoughts commune with the subtle and arcane.

From the *Lingbao Jade Capital Mountain Pace-the-Void Sutra*. At the conclusion of each verse, all proclaim "Excellent!" and bow once.

**Releasing the Weight: Reciting the Dignitary’s Great Thanksgiving**
All again recite the dharma-rank they have received.

The High Functionary faces north and offers profound thanks.
All officials and participants kneel in reverence.
The Perfected of Lingchong stands facing east.

**The Right Great Thanksgiving and Confession Text** derives from the *Yellow Register Simplified Scriptures* and the *Lingbao Supreme Ultimate Ritual Dignity Sutra*.

**The Ten Recitations**
1. First recitation: For the Dao, the Four Great Ones unite in virtue.
   May the seven generations of ancestors of this household be freed from sorrow and suffering,
   Ascend to the heavens, where clothing and sustenance arise naturally.

2. Second recitation: For the emperor and lords of the realm, may the Dao’s transformation flourish.
   May academies thrive in abundance, the imperial influence vast and expansive.
   May dignity and decorum be revered, witnessed by all under heaven.
   May the people proclaim great peace, and the barbarian tribes submit in awe.
   May evil and malevolence vanish day by day, and the worthy and sagely arise anew.

3. Third recitation: For the Dharma Master, may merit and virtue be greatly established.
   May teachings and transformations be luminous and far-reaching, all attaining flight as immortals.

4. Fourth recitation: For fellow aspirants, may they swiftly attain the immortal Dao,
   And in turn, guide and deliver one another.

5. Fifth recitation: For the nine relations, may harmony and concord prevail,
   Valuing the Dao above wealth, their conduct a model for all beings.

6. Sixth recitation: For those who humble themselves to bestow alms upon Daoists and the cold and hungry,
   May all people under heaven find their rightful place.

7. Seventh recitation: For the crawling and creeping, all sentient beings,
   May all universally receive accomplishment.

8. Eighth recitation: For the pardoning of this household’s transgressions from past lives,
   May karmic debts of life and death be resolved, merits established to redress faults.

9. Ninth recitation: For the flourishing of this household,
   May ancestral temples endure with descendants, and generations yield worthy talents.

10. Tenth recitation: For reverently receiving the Master’s scriptures, may we never falter in devotion.
    With equanimity and single-mindedness, may we broadly deliver all beings,
    Attain the rank of superior immortals, and ascend to heaven in broad daylight.
    May we bow before the Supreme Venerable and forever become perfected beings,
    Clad in robes of five-colored clouds, merging with the Dao as one.
    Alternately: Riding cloud chariots and feathered carriages, merging with the Dao as one.

**The Twelve Vows and Their Explications**
1. First vow: May the Great Dao be serene and devoid of desire, empty and tranquil,
   Abiding in stillness and clarity. May the gates of the Dharma be flung wide,
   Teaching and guiding the stubborn. May all attain wisdom and understanding,
   Cultivating with diligence and perseverance. May those who study together
   Universally ascend to the void, preserving harmony with heaven,
   Abiding in eternal peace without sorrow. May all sentient beings together know tranquility.

2. Second vow: May the various heavens congeal qi and settle in clarity,
   Their vast expanse high and encompassing, preserving truth and fortifying the numinous.
   May climate and seasons be harmonized, the four movements at peace.
   May nations be secure and people prosperous, all under heaven at rest.
   May all be broadly delivered, kindness extending to all living beings.
   May kalpas be preserved for eternity, enduring for countless eons without end.

3. Third vow: May the earth be vast and boundlessly supportive,
   Stable and unshaken, seas and abysses uncollapsed.
   May it safeguard and pacify the nation, the multitudes flourishing in reverence.
   May the living be nurtured and the dead at peace, kindness pervading the ten directions.
   May crops and plants thrive, daily abundance increasing.
   May the virtue of profound bearing be fulfilled, ten thousand wishes all realized.

4. Fourth vow: May the sun and moon, the two luminaries, shine in lofty brilliance,
   Free from eclipses or dimming, abiding in clarity and peace.
   May their light illuminate the heavens, dispelling all darkness.
   May kalpas be preserved and secured, worldly reigns at peace.
   May universal blessings and grace shower all sentient beings.

5. Fifth vow: May the stars, equal in radiance to the sun and moon,
   Revolve and shine, illuminating the ten directions.
   May each abide in its proper place, their paths straight and true.
   May they safeguard and pacify the nation, free from calamity.
   May the four seas be united in peace, all under heaven flourishing.

6. Sixth vow: May the four seasons progress in due order,
   Climate and qi harmonized, free from disaster or affliction.
   May plagues and poisons vanish, all under heaven at peace.
   May the five grains ripen in abundance, nations wealthy and people joyful.

7. Seventh vow: May floating clouds congeal qi and gather mist,
   Soaring high and settling in the void, shading the profound and mysterious.
   When concealed, they embody non-action; when dispersed, they fill the heavens.
   May immortals and perfected beings dwell together, forming friendships with the host of immortals.
   May kindness flow to all, nations cherished and people loved.
   May all beings be universally delivered, sharing the kalpa’s longevity.

8. Eighth vow: May wind and rain flow and shower without end,
   Universally bestowing their bounty, nurturing growth.
   May the myriad things flourish, nations stored with wealth and people prosperous.

9. Ninth vow: May the Five Peaks each abide in their proper direction,
   Towering and encompassing, forever serving as immortal palaces.
   May they safeguard the nation’s destiny, preserving heaven without end.
   May all be protected and delivered, none failing to revere their majesty.

10. Tenth vow: May rivers and seas be vast and boundless,
    Containing and embracing all, nurturing even the smallest.
    May their depths be gentle and kind, bestowing moisture upon all that breathes.
    May heaven and humanity rejoice, their years enduring like the kalpa’s stone.

11. Eleventh vow: May emperors and lords of nations daily prosper,
    The four seas at peace, weapons of war stilled.
    May heaven and humanity sing in praise, auspicious omens appearing.
    May teachings flourish in abundance, transformative influence vast and far-reaching.
    May the multitudes rejoice, eternal joy unceasing.

12. Twelfth vow: May the crawling and creeping, all that moves and breathes—
    Whether born or yet unborn—universally attain safety and fulfillment.
    May all perceive the primordial qi, receiving the form of yang.
    May grasses, trees, fruits, and forests endure winter without withering.
    May all be delivered, none failing to flourish in fresh splendor.

From the *Essential Explications of the Numinous Treasure True Writ*.

**Dedication of Merit**
The merits of repentance, recitation, scripture-transmission, and meditative turning accrued heretofore may be redirected as appropriate: above, for the benefit of state and sovereign; below, for the living and the deceased. Together, may the merits of fast and scripture-transmission become supreme causes, perfecting the unsurpassed Dao.

**Secret Petition for Pardon**
Each day, upon completing the fast and exiting the altar, before the Mystic Master, silently intone:
*"We, your servants, now undertake this fast and ascend the altar to perform the Dao on behalf of [Name], [Title]. We humbly fear that in our conduct we may have transgressed regulations, failed to conform to ritual propriety, drawn the censure of the Four Offices, or incurred the displeasure of the Five Emperors. For a thousand faults and ten thousand sins, we beseech your pardon, that our merits may be perfected and our petitions answered. We now reverently rely upon the boundless grace of the Great Dharma Master of the Mystic Center, the Three Officials, and the Five Emperors."*

**Completion of the Three Bows**

Compiled by Jiang Shuyu, Perfected Enforcer of the Dao and Transcendent Official

**Section on Fast Rites and Their Application**
*Explication of Verbal Merits, Prostration, and Memorial Presentation*

Master Du Guangcheng states: Memorial texts are to be written on yellow silk five *chi* in length, with vermilion borders and vermilion script, each line containing twenty-four characters. The character for "life" (*sheng*) must not appear at the bottom of a line, nor the character for "death" (*si*) at the top. The first line records the ritual rank in full, concluding with the phrase "kneeling with head bowed." The phrase "I humbly address" occupies its own line. "The Supreme Vastness of the Boundless Dao" begins the second line. After the memorial text, the phrase "we reverently submit" is separated by three lines from the petitioner’s surname. The sacred title is separated by three lines from the petitioner’s surname. The date is separated by three lines from the sacred title. All must conform to the prescribed format; no emendations or corrections are permitted, lest severe censure follow. Proceed with utmost care.

When reading the memorial, first pass the document over incense for purification, then recite the ritual rank. Rise, bow twice, and resume a long kneel. In a harmonious voice and with regulated *qi*, read aloud. At the mention of the disciple’s name, all present bow twice. At phrases expressing reverent trepidation, rise and bow twice again. Upon reaching the date, time, and place of submission, bow twice more. When finished, unfold the memorial upon the jade table, verifying its presentation before the throne. Secure it with a dragon-headed ritual knife to the left of the sacred title and a vermilion brush to the right. Next, offer three pinches of incense, kneel long, and strike the teeth three times. Conclude the dispatch of the memorial and the issuance of its mandate.

The Dharma Master stands behind the table, gazing toward the Gate of Heaven, bowing slightly. Within, he visualizes the Three and Five Officials, the generals of the Three Primes, the courier functionaries, and their mounted retinue arrayed before and behind him. His body ascends in a jade-feathered chariot drawn by dragons, borne aloft amid purple *qi*, rising gently to the threshold of the Three Heavenly Gates. First, he pays homage to the Dharma Masters of the Three Heavens, then enters the left gate of the Mystic Capital Palace to present the memorial. Holding the memorial case, he proceeds directly through the Three Heavenly Gates. Twelve attendants—bearing the memorial, presenting the petition, and performing related duties—await the celestial review. Once the memorial is received, they exit the Three Heavenly Gates, returning in the feathered chariot with their mounted escort. The sequence of celestial palaces and pathways traversed follows the same order as the Three-Five Memorial Rite.

Next, strike the teeth twelve times to conclude the inner rites, then three more times, swallowing saliva thrice. Visualize the Three-Five memorial officials returning to their respective positions within the body, then bow twice. Roll the memorial into its case, seal it, and place it with the true writ upon a small table. The table is borne forward, with the Fast Overseer verifying the seal, preceded by banners and staffs, the disciples following behind. At the Gate of Heaven, the memorial is burned. The Dharma Master, standing in his original position facing the Gate of Heaven, visualizes the true officials bearing the true writ and memorial ascending with the crimson flames of the incense smoke into the celestial gate.

The above describes the merits of verbal petitions, also called "verbal merit memorials." Memorials and petitions follow the same method, both rooted in the Orthodox Unity tradition. In ancient times, Register Disciples and Libationers, overseeing households and transforming the people, submitted memorials and petitions by adhering to the proper method, visualizing the dispatch of officials to present them, awaiting the mysterious response. Thus, the original scripture for dispatching memorials states: "Should there be errors or inversions, the long brush of the celestial scribe will correct them accordingly." Yang Jie, in his revision of the *Golden Canopy*, arbitrarily removed these thirty-eight characters, failing to grasp the ancient method. Once the visualization of submission is complete, the memorial is left in the care of the central administration. On the days of the Three Primes, it is burned according to the prescribed method for concluding memorials. Memorials submitted after the Upper Prime are concluded on the Middle Prime; those after the Middle Prime are concluded on the Lower Prime.

In ancient times, the Dharma Registers were complete, and transmission had a proper lineage. The Three and Five Officials and their soldiers responded to the breath, not merely to written documents. After Du Guangcheng received his official appointment, he began collecting memorials into their cases and burning them at the Gate of Heaven. This reflects the ancient method, though later transmissions lost their authenticity. Without relying on written documents, one could not expect a response. Thus, after dispatching the officials, the memorial is rolled into its case, and the Dharma Master, following the proper visualization, burns it immediately—a slight deviation from the ancient method. Later, Zhao Daosheng further altered the procedure, having the Dharma Master read the memorial from back to front after the phrase "we reverently submit," and pressing the memorial with a jade scepter three times—a method from the *Celestial Unity* tradition.

The *Scripture of the Five Refinements for Animating the Corpse* in the Numinous Treasure tradition contains the method for yellow silk memorials, which serves as a template. At the beginning of a fast, the officials are summoned to initiate proceedings. Upon completion, a memorial is submitted, accompanied by a decree of merits, which ascends with the memorial to the Mystic Capital to receive celestial rewards. The officials are not summoned again. When Yang Jie was commissioned to revise the ritual scriptures, he added a second invocation of the ritual rank and a re-summoning of the officials after the Three Bows at the dispersal of the altar. This practice persisted thereafter, though it was never part of the ancient method, having failed to thoroughly examine the scriptures.

**Explication of Summoning the Officials**
All officials kneel long. The Dharma Master strikes the teeth twelve times, concluding the summoning. He strikes the teeth three more times and swallows saliva thrice. Visualizing the Three-Five officials returning to their respective positions within the body.

**Explication of Dismissing the Offices**
Each official, in order of rank, bows once before the Three Treasures, kneels long, and receives the tally from the High Merit. Rising, they perform the Three Bows and retreat to stand in the west. The High Merit bows three times and returns to his position.

**Explication of Proclaiming the Tally**
First, offer three pinches of incense. Holding the mountain tally, strike the teeth nine times and read it aloud, passing it over the incense thrice before recitation. Upon finishing, all officials bow twice. A disciple holds the tally horizontally over the incense smoke. The Dharma Master strikes the teeth nine times and recites the incantation facing east. As he chants, the officials echo his words. Afterward, all bow twice to the tally and recite the four characters for "golden dragon courier transmission" three times. The incantation concludes, and the tally is sealed according to the proper method. The water and earth tallies follow the same procedure.

**Returning the Precepts and Hymn of Praise**
The Heavenly Worthy, in great compassion,
Proclaims the precepts to deliver sentient beings.
Majestic virtue pervades the hidden and manifest,
And karmic retribution moves the divine.
All heavens come to bow in reverence,
While demonic hordes restrain their forms.
The past transcends the eight difficulties,
The present secures a thousand years of life.
When the fast’s blessings are fulfilled,
Together we send forth our sincere devotion.
The floating Sanskrit hymn soars on the clouds,
Incense and fragrant smoke intermingle.

The Jade Phoenix mounts the cinnabar carriage,
The Golden Dragon draws the verdant chariot.
In life and death, all know joy,
In family and state, all is peace.

**Ode to the Great Ultimate, with Exegesis**
The Dao takes fasting as its foremost practice,
Diligent cultivation ascends the Golden Portal.
Thus is the great Dharma Bridge established,
Universally delivering all beings and things.
Repaying the virtue of past lives,
The mind of Dao arises transcendent.
The body soars to ascend the Mystic Capital,
And the seven ancestors all attain liberation.

**From the *Ritual of Fasting and Majestic Demeanor in the Great Ultimate Sutra***
**Hymn of Studying Immortality**
To study immortality is urgent,
To uphold the precepts restrains the pure heart.
In emptiness and equanimity, the upright *qi* abides,
Immortal sages naturally seek one another.
If you do not believe the Dharma’s words,
Why dwell in the mountains and forests?

**Hymn of the Cavernous Void, from the *Scripture of the Cavernous Void and Numinous Chapters of the Divine Treasure***
The Primordial Beginning unfurls the chart,
Spreading forth the jade tablets.
Chanting the Cavernous Void in lofty song,
One strides into the Mystery on flying steps.
Divine kings deliver life,
Riding the void and mounting the mist.
Reverently reciting the numinous chapters,
They endure as long as the kalpas.

**Hymn of the Three Paths and Five Sufferings**
The Three Powers and the myriad things,
Each relies on the other in their allotted years.
The beginning and end span the great kalpas,
When blessings are exhausted, heaven and earth collapse.
Coming and going through the Five Paths,
How bitter to cycle through death and rebirth!
Revolving within the Three Paths,
Departing and returning, ever bound to calamity.
The great worthy heeds this precept,
Enduring the world and severing attachments.
The foolish do not believe the Dharma,
Their sins and pains ever cling to them.
I grieve that the world’s suffering knows no end,
And so I proclaim it again, now and of old.
If you wish to escape this calamity,
Take refuge in the Most High Scripture.
Sin and blessing arise not from another,
But truly emerge from your own self.
The great worthy thus guards his speech,
Seeking to cut off all evil roots.
Extinguishing thoughts and returning to forgetfulness,
Relying and submitting, awaiting their final dissolution.
To propagate the Dao and pacify the world,
In the end, one shall behold the True and Real.
Lust and jealousy are the chief of calamities,
The greatest afflictions that destroy the body.
Covetousness and indulgence bring such disaster,
Inevitably leading to premature ruin.
To know evil yet not reform it,
How can this bring peace to the Dao?
Harboring poison while feigning purity,
I now utter a long sigh.
Karma from past lives is surely real,
Yet the weak and lost call it nonexistent.
All desire to see it before their eyes,
Dismissing what passes beyond their gaze as false.
The great worthy, enlightened to the Dao’s teachings,
Wields the axe to pity the stubborn.
Tenderly mindful of your suffering,
Diligently I cause myself sorrow.
Human life is easily spent,
Like a flame in the oil.
The Four Great Elements temporarily meet,
The Five Aggregates are but provisional.
In the prime of youth, one should study diligently,
Hastening to seek the preservation of self.
When blessings are exhausted, body and spirit scatter,
Plunging into the dark hells below.
The sagely fear this,
And so seek the Dao to escape this calamity.
To study immortality is urgent,
To uphold the precepts restrains the pure heart.
In emptiness and equanimity, the upright *qi* abides,
Immortal sages naturally seek one another.
If you do not believe the Dharma’s words,
Why dwell in the mountains and forests?
The great worthy delights in the scriptures and precepts,
Receiving them as treasures for the body.
To pursue study is ever belated,
To cultivate the self is ever too late.
By the time one unravels the profound and obscure,
In the blink of an eye, one is already old.
Clutching the scroll, one sighs to the utmost,
Only to face death’s agony and sorrow.
Thus in my youth, I abandoned the world
To study the Dao.

**Composed by the Perfected of the Great Ultimate, from the *Scripture of the Fundamental Vows of the Divine Treasure Precepts***

**Exegesis of the Lamps**
The *Yellow Register Petition* of the Lower Prime’s Divine Immortals states: For the majestic demeanor of delivering from the roots of sin, the ten directions each have nine lamps lit, totaling ninety lamps. Beyond the capital’s gates, lamps are lit at the year’s station, the great and lesser tombs, the life star, and beside the gates, as many as the host can arrange. Each must shine brightly, illuminating the night without ceasing, never allowing them to extinguish.

The *Yellow Register Petition*—though the number of lamps is fixed, one must measure their strength and the altar’s size to arrange them, ensuring they do not hinder the proceedings or soil the robes of the participants.

The *Golden Tally Petition* of the Upper Prime’s Divine Immortals states: The majestic demeanor of lighting lamps is of utmost merit and virtue. Above, it illuminates the heavens; below, it illuminates the earth. The eight directions and nine lands all behold its radiance. It rests entirely with the lamp-attending officers to diligently apply their minds. Each lamp must shine brightly throughout the night, never extinguishing or dimming. Those who cut off the world’s ties should ever be vigilant.

The Flying Heavenly Divine Persons say: If scholars do not understand the rites of lighting lamps and burning incense, their seven ancestors will not be delivered from the long-night’s abode, and in the Nine Dark Realms, their bodies will lack light, subject to the trials of the Dark Yin Bureau.

Master Du Guangcheng says: The rite of lighting lamps originates from the *Golden Register Petition*. In all fasting and Daoist practices, burning incense and lighting lamps are the most urgent tasks. Incense conveys fragrance and transmits sincerity, ascending to move the Perfected and Numinous. Lamps dispel darkness and illuminate the hidden, descending to open the underworld’s long night. Thus the precepts state: Burning incense and lighting lamps illuminate the heavens’ halls of blessing above and the long-night hells below. Suffering souls and stagnant spirits, riding this light, may attain liberation. Since lamps must be lit, each has its symbolic form. In spring, nine; in summer, three; in autumn, seven; in winter, five; and in the four seasons, twelve—all arranged according to the Five Phases’ fundamental numbers. There are also lamps for the various heavens and earths, the Eight Trigrams and Nine Dark Realms, each positioned according to the *Golden Register Petition*, with incense burned and prayers recited. Blessings and virtue descend at once, and disasters and misfortunes naturally dissipate. Whether on the night of the fast’s commencement or within three or seven days, lamps are lit according to the method, and after the evening’s practices conclude, one exits the altar to the earth’s gate. With hymns and chants, banners and staffs, in orderly and refined steps, the master leads the assembly of disciples to circumambulate beneath the lamps, reciting prayers at each position. After each prayer, the assembly bows. When all prayers are complete, the Cavernous Void’s chant guides them back before the Mystic Master, dispersing as in the usual rite. Even if only at the earth’s gate, arranging the ranks to pray and recite accords with the method.

It is further said: In all *Yellow Register* rites, one should follow the true texts and jade instructions. Beyond the four seasons’ lamps, one separately lights the *Golden Register* lamps, bowing and praying according to the method. Whether performing this within three days or praying for a single night, all will gain blessings and benefits, and both the hidden and manifest will receive grace. Even if not within a fasting altar, lighting these lamps and bowing according to the method yields equal merit.

The virtuous and noble should widely propagate this.

**Hymn of the Bright Lamp**
The Orthodox Unity’s yang-light,
Flaming upward in vermilion smoke.
Twelve Divine Lads of Illumination,
Pervading all under heaven and our own bodies.
A hundred evils shattered and cast down,
Ten thousand demons repelled.
Radiance clear and luminous,
Communing with the true and reaching the numinous.
Ascending into the formless,
Merging with the Dao in spontaneity.

*From the* Orthodox Numinous Treasure’s *Upper Prime Golden Register Simplified Texts, True Immortals’ Section: Ritual of Lighting Lamps*

*From the* Upper Prime Golden Register Simplified Texts, True Immortals’ Section: Ritual of Lighting Lamps*

**Explanation of Presenting the Dragon Tablet**
The *Lower Prime Yellow Register Simplified Texts, Numinous Immortals’ Section* states: For the ritual of delivering from the roots of transgression, when the fast is fully completed, one should follow the jade instructions and present one golden dragon tablet. Inscribed with cinnabar on a jade slip, bound with azure silk, it serves as a token of ascent and deliverance to the numinous mountain. It is hung in the midst of sheer cliffs, strictly adhering to the full method.

It further states: For the ritual of summoning the Water Thearch’s power, one should inscribe cinnabar on a jade slip, attach one golden dragon tablet, bind it with azure silk, and sink it into the Three Rivers as a token of ascent and deliverance to the Water Thearch, strictly following the jade instructions and complete text.

It further states: When the summoning of the Water Thearch is complete, take nine jade slips, golden dragon tablets, and golden buttons, bind them with azure silk, and bury them at the altar site to report and covenant with the Earth Official, entirely according to the ritual statutes.

The *Jade Tablet Covenant with the True Statutes* states: When performing the *Yellow Register* precious fast, one should use three taels of superior gold to cast golden dragons. Each dragon weighs one tael. The state uses superior gold, nobles and high ministers use secondary gold, scholars and commoners may use silver or bronze gilded, all of which are permissible, accompanied by the tablet text. The jade slip should record the purpose of the fast, the state’s reign title, the year, month, and day, the Dharma Master’s name, and the location of the offering, then cast it into famous mountains and caverns, numinous springs and dragon lairs, or the fast’s altar or its vicinity, to covenant with the Three Treasuries of Heaven, Earth, and Water, allowing them to witness and verify the fast’s merit. Those who neglect this will be examined by the Nine Offices of the Earth Official.

The statutes say: The dragon rides the clouds’ qi, governs yin and yang, coalesces to form a body, disperses to compose patterns, its transformations unfathomable, entering earth and ascending heaven. Thus, the thirty-six heavens, the utmost yang’s realm, can serve as couriers to transmit messages, communicating with the mysterious and numinous—such is the dragon. The dragon is a yang creature. Of heaven’s uses, none surpass the dragon; of earth’s uses, none surpass the tortoise; of humanity’s uses, none surpass the horse. Thus, in heaven, dragons serve as couriers, coming and going among humans. Gold is the foremost of the five metals, unyielding and unchanging, treasured by heaven and earth, communicating with the numinous and uniting with the divine. Therefore, superior gold is used to cast it in the dragon’s form, presenting it to cavernous palaces to covenant with the Three Primes. The true officials of cavernous palaces, their subordinate offices, receive the dragon token and tablet text, record its good merits, and memorialize them to the Most High. The response to this resonance is like a shadow following form. Those who cultivate and esteem this must not neglect it.

The tablet is for reporting, recording, and inscribing. It records the world’s goodness and reports to the Highest Perfected. Its length is one foot and two inches, symbolizing the twelve earthly branches. Its width is two inches and four fen, corresponding to the twenty-four true qi. Its thickness is two fen, symbolizing the Two Modes. Its top and bottom are square, corresponding to the sun’s square radiance, upright and true, penetrating and reaching without avoidance or evasion. The state uses jade for it, as jade possesses nine virtues and can serve as a token for rites to the great earth spirits, hence jade is used. Nobles, ministers, and commoners universally use hibiscus wood, as its purity and fine texture can compare to jade, clarifying the distinction between noble and base.

The jade disk is a treasure for rites to heaven, earth, and mountains and rivers, made of jade. For mountain tablets, use one round disk, its color blue-green, two inches in diameter, hollow in the center. The mountain tablet serves as a token to the Nine Heavens, hence a blue-green disk is used, corresponding to heaven and earth. For water tablets, use a six-pointed disk, its color black, three inches in diameter, hollow in the center. The water tablet serves as a token to the Nine Seas’ Water Officials, hence a dark disk is used, the color of water. Six points correspond to water’s number. For earth tablets, use a yellow disk, square, two inches in diameter, hollow in the center. The earth tablet serves as a token to the Nine Earths, yellow being earth’s color. Square corresponds to earth’s form. The disk and dragon accompany the sealed tablet, bound with azure silk.

The method for presenting the three tablets uses nine golden buttons. Three tablets use twenty-seven buttons. Golden buttons replace the blood oath, azure silk replaces cutting hair, conveying sincerity in covenant, most weighty. Therefore, azure silk binds the buttons and disk, attaching them to the tablet and dragon, and only then are they released. The button method: the state uses gold; ministers and commoners may use silver or bronze gilded. The button’s diameter is nine fen, its exterior round like a ring.

Upon completing the purification fast, select an auspicious day—or the very day of the fast—to prepare the offering feast. The ritual master, assembled officials, the fast’s sponsor, and disciples either sail by boat to the water cavern or ascend by land to the mountain gate. Outside the cavern, they clear the grass, sweep, and purify the ground, then arrange the offering mats. Wine, fruit, viands, dried venison, broth, tea, and other items are set forth: sixty portions for the state, twenty-four for ministers and commoners. Following the solemn rite’s protocol, they don robes, bathe, rinse their mouths, and pay homage in the ritual proceedings, adhering strictly to the prescribed forms.

The local divine officers, inspectors, and guardian officials must act as intermediaries, opening the cavern’s gates to the celestial bureaus within, transmitting the fast’s inscribed tablets. Thus, blessings and virtue are swiftly realized. No one may omit the gate-opening and directly cast the tablets into the cavern, for such neglect fails to reach the true spirits and instead invites punishment. Should the mountain or water cavern lie too distant for the entire assembly to travel or ascend, select one or two ritual officers from the altar, along with disciples, to bear the tablets to the cavern. There, they perform the offering rites, open the gates, and present the tablets exactly as prescribed.

When the state presents the Dragon Tablets to the Five Peaks and other sacred mountains, the Golden Register’s protocols apply, differing in complexity from these ordinary rites. If the fast’s sponsor is constrained by public or private duties and cannot personally visit the cavern, choose one devout, reverent, and trustworthy attendant to perform the rites in their stead. If no substitute is available, the master may act as intermediary to transmit the tablets. Under no circumstances may the inscribed tablets be concealed or delayed, for such neglect breaches the covenant’s faith. The local divine officers will record and report the lapse, and the resulting offense is no trifling matter—take utmost care.

*End of Scroll Thirty-Five of the* Instant Rites of the Supreme Yellow Register Great Fast
*Scroll Thirty-Six of the* Instant Rites of the Supreme Yellow Register Great Fast

At the outset of establishing the fast, the *Investiture Prayer* is offered:

Vast and formless, the empty void,
Endless, it moves the numinous.
Reverence draws Heaven’s grace,
Neglect invites demonic intrusion.
Fortune and misfortune turn with fate,
Adversity and prosperity arise from karmic conditions.
The Dao does not prize pearls or jade,
The gods respond only to utmost sincerity.
With redoubled devotion, exhaust all toil,
With earnest sincerity, pour forth the heart’s truth.
Thus the Great Dao is naturally attained,
And all receive the descent of true spirits.
Holding incense, we state our vows,
Bowing our heads in reverence to exalted purity.
The Heavenly Worthy abides in serene quiescence,
Turn the heart to worship the distant and obscure.

Gather faith and circulate the cinnabar sincerity.

True qi mingles with fragrant smoke.

The Scriptural Treasures of the ten directions.
May all beings open their minds to awakening,
Receiving, upholding, reciting, and transmitting.

With utmost sincerity, we take refuge in
The Master Treasures of the ten directions.
May all beings universally ascend the Dharma bridge,
Without obstruction.

*Hymn on Hearing the Scriptures*

May all beings have their myriad transgressions forever dissolved,
And the sprouts of goodness grow ever stronger.

After hearing the scriptures,
May all beings deeply enter the Dharma gate,
Taking refuge with faith and acceptance.

After hearing the scriptures,
May all beings forever sever delusion,
Constantly cultivating the supreme Dao.

*Dao Hymn*

Each directing their minds,
Take refuge in the Three Treasures, the supreme and venerable,

*Merit Recitation for the Officials*
*Inviting the Master Hymn*

**Hymn for Sending Forth the Five Emperors**

**Hymn for Sending Forth the Water Official**

**Eulogy of the White Crane**
The Perfected of the Great One, with a countenance of ice and snow,

Clouds linger at the window, the crane perches in the pine.

The white crane descends from the Nine Heavens,

Sun and moon hasten, mortals age swiftly—

The wondrous bird, born of transformation, cries in the Nine Heavens,
Snow-white feathers, cinnabar crown—both gleam resplendent.
