**End of Volume Fifty-Six of the *Supreme Yellow Register Great Fast Rite Standard Procedures***
**Beginning of Volume Fifty-Seven of the *Supreme Yellow Register Great Fast Rite Standard Procedures***
**Appendix: Record of the Book’s Composition**

My late father, Master of the Fast, posthumously named **Chúyú**, courtesy name **Dézhān** (formerly **Xiāohán**), of the Jiang clan.
From the Liang dynasty’s *Tōngpǔ* era, our family resided in Yóngjiā. His great-grandfather was named **Fú**; his grandfather, **Dūn**, posthumously honored as *Zhòng Dàfū*. His father, **Xíngjiǎn**, served as *Cháo Yì Dàfū*, Prefect of Chǔzhōu, posthumously honored as *Zhòng Fèng Dàfū*.

In the *Shàoxī* era, *Rénzǐ* year, my father was granted the title *Dífēng Láng* through imperial favor and served as the *Hùyàn* (accounting clerk) of Yángzhōu. During times of fiscal hardship, he was renowned for his integrity. When the *Zhōng Fèng* passed away, Governor Hóng of the *Shàodào* deeply lamented his loss. Later, when stationed in Lín’ān to oversee the *Shàn Dīngsūn* (military conscription), he was tasked with managing the *Rénhé Yánchǎng* (salt fields). The *Tínghù* (village households) were rebellious and disruptive, repeatedly undermining his governance. My father enforced strict financial regulations, and all acknowledged his impartiality, fearing his authority while cherishing his benevolence. After three years, his performance exceeded expectations, and he was specially promoted to *Chéngzhí Láng*, serving as the *Jūn Jiétuī* (military administrator) of Yuèzhōu.

In the *Yǐhài* year, a drought and locust plague ravaged the region for several years. He submitted petitions to the *Lù Yù* (Provincial Administration) for relief measures, actively implementing policies to aid the starving. Markets remained stable, and no one in the countryside went hungry. When a false accusation arose against the Lǐ family for worshipping a wild shrine, my father investigated their household, uncovering the full truth through official records. After one interrogation, he exposed the deceit, exonerating all involved—saving dozens from execution. By the end of *Chúnxī*, the *Zhōng Fèng*’s governance brought prosperity, and the people erected shrines in his honor at Liángshān and at the site where my father had cleared the Lǐ family’s name. Those wronged wept along the road, saying: *"We knew he was the son of Magistrate Jiang."*

Later, he served as *Chéng* of Yǒngxīn in Jìzhōu, where he was quickly recommended for merit and transferred to *Yìyáng Xiàn* in Xìnzhōu. The county’s administration had long been corrupt; monthly tribute to the *Jiānghuái* armies and monthly remittances to *Huáidōng* drained the treasury, often exceeding allocated quotas. Outlying regions suffered from exhaustion, and the people, burdened by oppressive taxes, resorted to deceit and usury, with many ruined by forced labor. My father personally reviewed the registers, rooting out official malfeasance, and governed with simplicity, prioritizing the people’s grievances. He resolved long-standing disputes, relieving wronged parties, and adjusted tax burdens to ease the pressure of collections. He suppressed powerful local bullies to protect the virtuous. When officials and scholars presented petitions outlining local hardships, he acted immediately. His policies reached even the most remote villages, where elders and scholars gathered in awe, singing his praises in verse—news of his governance spread to the imperial court.

The ancestral temples and ritual altars had fallen into disrepair, and the *Shī* (shrines) were neglected. My father restored them all, planting appropriate vegetation. Schools, granaries, and official halls that had decayed were repaired at his expense, using funds from his own administrative surplus—unlike previous officials who embezzled for personal gain. He ensured no one remained unjustly imprisoned, and even the most vulnerable—widows, orphans, and the destitute—received fair hearings without delay. His devotion to the people was absolute, sparing no effort.

His subordinates worked tirelessly, day and night, forgetting to take breaks.

His life ended from grief and diligent service, his illness already impairing his vision. Though the official documents were as yet unfulfilled, he still entrusted his deputy, saying, *"Do not relax the county laws."* He knelt in prayer to the heavens, sat upright, and passed away on the twenty-sixth day of the first month of the *Jiādìng* era (1217), at the age of sixty-two.

He had accumulated the rank of *Chéngyì Láng* (Honorary Advisor), and in the year *Xīnyǐ* (1083), he was granted the *Míngtáng* (Ennobled by Imperial Ancestral Temple) title, with the privilege of wearing the five-rank official attire. Alas, how grievous it is!

My father, in his youth, was precociously bright and discerning, with keen intellect and a luminous spirit. He studied widely across ancient and modern texts, never tiring, and could recite from memory whatever he read once or twice. He was earnest and sincere, never speaking frivolously, and his nature was noble yet gentle, his breadth of mind vast and harmonious. Those who knew him found him distant, never seeing the colors of his joy or anger.

He mastered the *Táng Lǜ* (Tang Dynasty legal codes), their style austere yet refined, and found his own delight in them. His ambition was not content with small achievements, and he explored countless schools of thought. Celestial phenomena, earthly geography, the cycles of *qì* (cosmic breath), calendrical systems, granary techniques, and *Yúfāng* (medical prescriptions), as well as *Gānxīng* (astronomical divination) and *wūxué* (occult studies)—he delved deeply into all. Yet, above all, he was captivated by the essence of *Hùnyuán Dàodé* (the supreme Dao/Virtue of the cosmos).

In the year *Yǐnguāng* (1205) of the *Qìngyuán* era, *Chóngjìng* (Master of Serenity) invited my father to *Bùcáng* (Bracketed Mountains). My father met him in the *Yānyǔlóu* (Misty Rain Tower), and they discussed ancient ritual methods. Their tastes aligned in the profound, and thus their friendship was sealed. In the years *Jǐwù* (1318) and *Rénxū* (1322), he revisited *Chóngjìng*’s *Zhúgōng* (Bamboo Study), engaging in thorough discussions.

*Chóngjìng* praised him highly and entrusted him with all the insights gained from his *Jīngshū* (Upland Shrine) masters and reclusive sages. My father mastered their transformations and applied them, and his methods always proved effective.

Whether in urgent or leisurely matters, he never refused to answer. His strange and miraculous cures were renowned, and his responses to inquiries were swift and precise. *Chóngjìng* said to my father: *"Take the Three Caverns True Scriptures as the foundation of the Dao/Way, and regard the Ten Directions’ Repentance as genuine sincerity. Devote your thoughts to the Nine Dynasties, and submit your petitions in triplicate. Such are the rituals as they should be. The convoluted, deceptive, and illusory are not the way."*

He also said: *"The salvation of beings is boundless; the myriad paths converge in the One Dao. The Master *Táidìng Tiān* (Master of Tranquil Virtue) resides in the place where his teachings are transmitted, yet his methods are limited to saving the dying, averting celestial disasters, pacifying emperors, and warding off malevolent influences. What is lacking is the means to guide both heaven and humanity. Why not expound upon the scriptures’ intent and supplement what Master *Táidìng Tiān* did not complete—would that not be excellent?"*

My father pondered deeply his teacher’s lessons, lamenting the corruption of contemporary customs, following the trends without return, indulging in superficiality while abandoning substance, and truncating the remnants of genuine tradition. He practiced vocal recitation for mere pleasure, relying on hollow symbols and echoing influences to feign divinity. As false doctrines spread and perverse teachings proliferated, he systematically reviewed ancient texts, tracing their origins and examining all his teacher’s past experiences and esoteric writings. He pored over every scroll and manuscript, night and day, by the light of his *yíngchuáng* (lamp like a firefly) and *hánjiàn* (cold wick), tirelessly copying and annotating them.

For the vulgar and shallow language of these texts, he refined and corrected it; for their erroneous practices, he clarified and dismantled them. Where teachings diverged in intent, he harmonized them into unity; where rituals were disordered, he pruned and restored them to their proper form.

He compiled the *Huánglù Zhāiyí* (Sacred Rituals of the Yellow Scrolls) into thirty-six volumes, the *Zìrán Zhāiyí* (Natural Rituals) into fifteen volumes, and the *Dùrén Xiūzhāi Xíngxiāng Sòngjīng Yí* (Rituals for Guiding Beings, Observing Rituals, and Reciting Scriptures) into twenty-four volumes. In total, he called his work the *Língbǎo Yùjiǎn* (Jewel Mirror of the Numinous Treasure), comprising seventy-five volumes.

He began in the *Jiātài Rénxū* year (1204) and completed it in the *Jiādìng Guǐwǔ* year (1213), spanning twenty years of labor. Such was his devotion to upholding the great teachings.

Disciples like *Zhū Suì* (Master Zhu), *Lín Yáofú* (Master Lin), *Chén Zìchéng* (Master Chen), and *Zhào Xīhuǒ* (Master Zhao) followed his methods.

As he lay dying, he told *Xīyīng* (Master Xi) and others: *"Death is the fate of life; wealth and honor are decrees of heaven. My work has fortunately reached completion, yet my great destiny arrives suddenly. If I die, you must return my writings to the ancestral shrine. Perhaps the ritual methods will thus continue to flourish, and the living and the dead may find reliance in them—then my hopes will be fulfilled."*

For a scholar’s conduct, it is only necessary to avoid associating with those inferior to oneself. With these words, he closed his eyes and departed.

After his passing, his body remained as if alive. Alas, heaven! How profound it is that, at the threshold of death and life, he remained unshaken—my father had truly attained the core principles of *Dàodé* (Dao/Virtue) and *Xuányuán* (the Primordial Source)!

We, his disciples, grieved deeply and endured bitterness, reverently following his final instructions. We meticulously reviewed and verified his writings four times, then sealed them in a hidden mountain.

Moreover, we appended his official career and major deeds, recording the beginning and end of his life, so that future generations may have something to study. In the seventh month of the *Jiādìng Guǐwǔ* year (1213), his unfilial son, *Fǎmíng Chōngsù* (Master of Serenity, posthumously ordained), and *Xiānyīng* (Master Xi), his disciple, wept blood and inscribed this with utmost care.

**Record of Master *Chóngjìng* (Master of Serenity) *Liú Yòngguāng* (Use Light, courtesy name *Dàohuī*), of the *Liú* (Leave) clan, originally from the *Héluò* (River Luo) region.**

His sixth-generation ancestor served in the *Táng* (Tang), holding the rank of *Yīnqīng Guānglù Dàfū* (Silver Green Light and Grand Minister).

In the Five Dynasties period, his family relocated to Jìnjiāng in Quánzhōu. When the Song Dynasty rose and pacified the four quarters, his fifth-generation ancestor, endowed with extraordinary talent, traveled westward through the Jiānghuái region, passing through Shàngráo Prefecture, and was captivated by the noble Yǔnxī Cloud Peak Mountain, where he settled.

His father, Fā, cultivated purity and virtue, embodying the upright demeanor of an ancient gentleman. Together with his wife, Lady Zhān, they received the *fǎjiào* (initiation rites) from the Longhú Shān (Dragon Tiger Mountain) under the guidance of the Heavenly Master. One night, he dreamed of the Han-era Heavenly Master, who bestowed upon him an elixir, saying: *"Consume this, and you shall have a son who will grow weary of worldly life."* Thus, she conceived.

Master *Chóngjìng* was born with innate brilliance and ancient grace, disciplined and dignified in bearing. From his youth, he grasped profound Daoist learning and received the Way from the Daoist priest Cài Yuǎnjiǔ of the Shàngqīng Zhēngyī Palace. Cài Yuǎnjiǔ, during the Xuān Hé era, held the title of *Tàisù Dàfū* (Grand Master of Supreme Purity) and was registered in the *Níngshén Diàn* (Hall of Concentrated Spirit), being the third-generation descendant of Wáng Dàojiān.

After taking the Daoist vows, he upheld his resolve with unwavering resolve, maintaining singular focus and profound depth. He delved into the arcane, uncovering hidden meanings and traversing perilous paths. Whether examining *jīnjiǎn yùzì* (golden tablets and jade inscriptions), *qióngzhuàn lánghán* (jade seals and bronze cases), the ten *dòng* (caverns) of vital precepts, or the inner texts of the *Sānhuáng* (Three Sovereigns), he mastered their essence and clarified their lineages.

The *sutra* of all Daoist teachings was without exception mastered, with particular devotion to the *Yùfǔ Wǔléi* (Five Thunder Laws of the Jade Treasury) and the *Zhèngyī* (Orthodox Unity) as his core doctrines. In secret, he practiced *yuánliàn* (primordial refinement) for thirty years.

Emperor Xiàozōng, moved by his loyalty, bestowed upon him the title *Xīyí* (Recluse of the Western Peak) and granted him the favor of nine respite days. He was entrusted with great governance over the three administrative circuits.

In a year of severe drought, the prefectural governor, Lord Shěn, constructed a ritual platform, having heard of his mastery over wind and thunder. He was summoned with great ceremony. Upon arrival, the priest inscribed talismans with seals, commanding officials and spirits to assemble with the might of rivers and mountains—all in solemn order. The officials, farmers, and elders alike marveled in awe.

That very day, torrential rain fell, flooding the four borders. The governor and above reported the drought at court. The emperor, delighted by the report, summoned him to the capital, lodging him in the *Tàiyī* (Great Unity) Palace, and commanded him to perform the rain-summoning rites as before. He also engraved an iron talisman, driving away the Dragon Master.

Soon after, the rain poured down furiously, like a deluge. The Western Lake and the Grand Canal, once parched and impassable by boat, were now overflowing. The emperor dispatched an imperial attendant with a decree, ordering the Dragon to return. In an instant, the clouds dispersed, and sunlight broke through. The emperor was greatly pleased, summoning him to the *Xuǎndé* (Select Virtue) Hall, where he bestowed lavish praise and rewards. He was granted a golden seal, appointed *Yòujiē Dàolù* (Right Street Daoist Master), and honored as a *gāoshì* (High Sage). After returning to his mountain retreat, a year passed before imperial messengers hurried to summon him along the way—only to encounter rain. Turning to the envoys, he said:

*"My prayers have been long. If Heaven does not divide its boundaries, how could the rain follow my carriage upon arrival?"*

The emperor replied: *"Indeed, your conduct is pure and lofty, your sincere devotion moving even the heavens."*

He inscribed an eight-character decree, which, upon receiving, the priest humbly declined, saying: *"Your Majesty’s virtue stirs the heavens—how could the rain disobey? My sincerity is but foolishness; what power could I possess?"*

When winter brought no snow, he was commanded to perform rites, invoking the mountain rivers and hundred spirits, and snow fell to a depth of a foot. The emperor marveled even more.

When the noble consort Liu of the *Déshòu* (Longevity and Virtue) Palace passed away, the palace conducted *Huángluó* (Yellow Talisman) rites. That night, there were strange sounds, as if the spirit of Lady Li had appeared. He was summoned to the private audience hall, where he was consulted on matters of ghosts and spirits. He replied:

*"The interplay of yin and yang is the Dao. Ghosts and spirits are the unfathomable manifestations of yin and yang. They coalesce into form, dispersing as *qi*. The Daoist method of gathering *qi* to restore spirit reveals their true nature."*

The emperor agreed.

*"Moreover, within the Daoist laws lies the essential doctrine of Orthodox Unity, its texts profound yet comprehensive. Why not compile an annotated commentary, to be presented to the throne for engraving and dissemination?"*

The *qí* (fortune) of the *jì* (fate) was again fulfilled, and he returned to serve the *dàoshū* (Daoist Master) in charge of the *Guójiāo* (orthodox teaching) gates. He oversaw the affairs of the *Lónghǔshān* (Dragon Tiger Mountain) and the *Shàngqīng* (Upper Clarity) *Zhèngyī* (Orthodox Unity) Palace.

When *Guāngzōng* (Emperor Guangzong) ascended the throne by *shòu* (receiving the imperial seal), he happened to violate the *yùshòu* (auspicious longevity) taboo. The emperor wore a worried expression, and commanded him to perform Daoist rites of *fá* (Dao) purification and exorcism. Suddenly, a towering spirit appeared, disheveled hair and sword drawn, standing in the palace hall. The attendants were struck with awe.

The emperor himself remained serene and unperturbed. The two palaces rejoiced in harmony. He was granted the title *Chōngjìng Xiānshēng* (Mr. Pacifying Tranquility), but he declined.

After the emperor’s enthronement, he prayed for snow. That night, he conducted the *Lǜzhāng* (Green Talisman) rites, and the stars and constellations still hung scattered and bright. At dawn, he reported the joyful snowfall to the throne, and the emperor marveled at it, promoting him to *zuǒjiē Dàolù* (Left Street Daoist Registrar) and then to *Tàiyī* (Supreme Unity) Palace *dūjiàn* (Superintendent).

In the year *rénxū* (1612, by the *Zhūyòu* cycle), there was a drought. The emperor entrusted him with the task of summoning rain, and he was just ascending the ritual platform to perform the rain-appeasing *fá* (Dao) when the sound of rain suddenly echoed like the roar of rivers and seas. The emperor said, *"Retain your service—you are a rain-maker."* He was granted imperial calligraphy on *yásimpli* (jade tablets).

The following year, there was again a lack of rain. He spoke to the inner palace hall: *"I am but a humble grass and reed, year after year beseeching Heaven. If the Celestial Sovereign has chastisement, my guilt is unforgivable. The *Huángguān* (Yellow Crown) *jìjiǔ* (Sacrificial Officer), how dare I monopolize the rites for the dead?"* The emperor replied, *"Plead for my sake—Heaven truly praises you. Do not decline."* At that moment, rain fell, and the *jiāosì* (ritual sacrifices to Heaven and Earth) were completed. He paid thanks at the *Tàiyī* Palace and was transferred to the *zuǒyòu jiē Dàolù* (Registrar of Both Left and Right Streets).

One day, he suddenly said, *"Life has bounds, knowledge knows no end. To let the bound follow the unbound—this is surely my folly."* He added, *"A scholar should not linger in celestial peaks or vanish in misty forests, nor should he tarry in the capital, troubling the worldly sovereign. This is my fault."* He begged earnestly to be allowed to return home. Though summoned by imperial edict four times, he declined each time due to illness.

On the New Year’s Day, he visited the *Dìshì Zhēnwǔ* (Emperor’s True Martial) Palace and took his leave with a smile. Someone asked, *"Where are you going?"* He replied, *"To wander in the realm of *Wúhéyǒu* (No-Where)."* Again, someone asked, *"Will you visit the *Báiyù Jīng* (White Jade Capital), or pay respects at the *Pénglái Dǎo* (Penglai Isle)?"* He answered, *"A fleeting thought arises—this is called *wàngxiǎng* (delusive fancy). The Great Sage’s perspective is boundless; who comes and who goes?"* Then, he entered his chamber, sat upright, and ascended.

One day, after seven days, his complexion remained as if alive—was this not truly the *shījiě* (corpse dissolution) spoken of?

His posthumous memorial reached the Emperor, who sighed and lamented. He bestowed fragrant gifts and funeral stipends, and provided the rites and proclamations for his burial.

Since his residence in the *Zhúgōng* (Bamboo Palace), noble families of princes, ministers, and high officials all invited him with utmost respect, hosting grand feasts and open prayers, seeking *dàowèn shòufǎ* (Dao/Way and teachings) from him. All came with sincerity and exertion, each finding favor in his presence.

With talismanic water to aid others, and rescue for those in peril without recourse, his footsteps outside their doors were as if he knew them by name.

Through endless nights of inscribing *zhuàn* (divinatory scripts), he never grew weary in his dealings with people.

For those who refused to sell charms, he provided funds for *zhāijiào* (vegetarian feasts and exorcisms), meticulously following the ancient texts.

He often said: *"Men use their emotions to petition the imperial gate—how could there be no way to reach the Emperor?"*

In drafting petitions and memorials, he expressed what others could not: his eloquent, nuanced compositions on matters of *zhāngcí* (proclamations), *biǎoshū* (memorials), *diéxí* (edicts), and *jièshì* (exhortations and oaths) numbered in the hundreds, not a single one flawed.

Across *Jiāngzhè* (the Jiangnan region), ten thousand *huánglù dà zhāijiào* (Yellow Banner Grand Exorcism Feasts) were established, and the *jǐngyǐng* (miraculous responses) were so profound that records were filled to overflowing.

One day, the *Shòukāng Huánghòu* (Empress Dowager Shou Kang) summoned him to the palace for a grand exorcism, honoring the *Xīngdì* (Star Emperor) with twelve hundred offerings, each of vast wealth and splendid ritual.

The overseers remarked: *"The Master is already wealthy."*

He smiled without replying, and after the rites were completed, he gathered the Star Emperor’s offerings and banknotes, burning them all together.

He then distributed gold to the *Xīnzhēng Yīgōng* (New Year’s Palace) within the Imperial City, storing tens of *láng* (hall chambers) worth, surpassing even the treasures of *Jiāngnán* (the southern Jiang region).

He also donated to the scriptural repositories of all departments.

For ruined temples, collapsed bridges, and broken paths, he repaired and restored them, his relief for the destitute and aid to the urgent being most fervent.

As in the case of *Yángshì* (Yang Family) revived from ashes, *Zháishì* (Zhai Family) vindicated in court, *Róngyī* (Rong’s son) saved from drowning, and *Zhèngzhuàn* (Zheng’s descendants) spared from unjust fate—his deeds were especially praised.

*Zǐsī* (Master Zisi) said, *"Utmost sincerity can exhaust one’s nature."* But he went further, exhausting the nature of all people and all things.

*Mèngzǐ* (Master Mencius) spoke of *"the benevolent will that extends even to the unknowable spirits."* His practices were indeed devoted to the *chōngmì* (sublime and secret) and the *qínzhì* (ardent and profound).

In aligning the heart with the *Tian* (Heavenly), and in *shìtiān* (serving Heaven), his only concern was *shè* (parsimony).

In connecting with the *língguǐ* (spirits and ghosts), his *rén* (benevolence) encompassed both the living and the dead.
